“Well, stopit,” Neferoy chastised, though there was humour in her voice, “Victorina told me about how much enervation you’ve got to throw around. Learn the damn Manastone enchantment so we can see about making a bunch.”

“Alright, alright,” I conceded, “Aren’t there any other enchantments we could work on in the meantime though? Ones where it won’t increase the risk of a Fumble too much if I don’t actually know the spell?”

“Fumble?” Kennocha asked, with furrowed brows.

“Mishap, whatever,” I said, “An armouring enchantment or something?”

“Even that needs to be done in layers,” Neferoy said, with a shake of her head, “And with enough layers, the chances that at least one of the castings will be a failure adds up.”

“What about something simpler than that?” Victorina asked, turning to Neferoy, “An enchantment that isn’t cast in layers.”

“There’s plenty, but it’s all just simple stuff. And you were the one that told me we needed to work on something that would bring in some proper money,” Neferoy replied, “It’s just not worth the time it would take.”

“Its fine, it won’t take me that long to get a proper grasp of the spell. I’ll start on it after dinner,” I promised, “My Antman impersonation can wait.”

“Antman?” I was asked, by about everyone at once.

“You know what, Manastone after, movie night first.”

-----

Most of the others didn’t really understand much of what was going on, but it seemed at least like everyone had a fun time. I’d been wanting to have a movie night since I figured out how to magnify my phone’s screen with an illusion, and this had been a good opportunity. Brandy especially seemed to enjoy it, and she seemed noticeably more… relaxed I guess? After having had watched it.

“Hey Quinn?” she asked, once the others had packed up for the night, “Thanks. It was like, super great and everything.”

“You’re welcome,” I smiled, “That is the one thing I miss about Earth, no more Marvel movies, and no more video games.”

“Really? Just movies and games?” she asked, and while her long hair hid her face as she looked down at the floor, I could see that tell that she was pretty serious about this.

“Pretty much, yeah,” I responded, “I’m not really a people person Brandy. I guess I miss my family, but it doesn’t really bother me. I’m not like most people though Brandy, I don’t think I’m a very good person to judge yourself by.”

She nodded slowly, before speaking “So if someone offered you the chance to go home, would you take it?”

“Fuck no,” I said firmly, “I go back to Earth and I’m just a boring computer nerd lost in a sea of other boring computer nerds. Here on Elardia, I can actually make a difference.”

“You’re lucky,” she said, not quite holding back tears, “At least you know stuff. I don’t know anything useful. The only thing I could have done was tell Vicky all about the number stuff, and I didn’t even know that was important until after you explained it all, way better than I ever could,” she sighed a heavy sigh, and it threatened to become a sob, “I just hate everything and want to go home. I’m never going to see anyone I ever cared about ever again. My boyfriend, my mom, my dad, my sisters, and all my friends, it’s like the Banestorm just came through and just fucking killed them all,” then she did start to cry.

It wasn’t a lot, no moaning sobs, no wailing, but I could see some gentle tears streaming down her cheeks, “This is all bullshit, it’s not fair. Doesn’t it make you sad Quinn? How can you just keep on going like nothing’s happened?” she demanded.

“I don’t know,” I said honestly.

I didn’t really even know what to say to her, she was sad, sure, but it was not as if life had been hard on her. She’d lived a privileged life before, more so than most westerners, and more so even than me, and I knew that I’d had it pretty good back on Earth. And it wasn’t like her life now was any less privileged. Not only had she been picked up within hours of landing here, while I’d risked my freedom and my life to get here, she also had power and money dropped into her lap. The number of people at the University with more magical talent than her could be counted on two fifths of one hand, and with that magical talent had come a hell of a lot of money. She had the power to remake reality, and was paid in a month, what the average elf wouldn’t earn in a decade.

*And she’s bitching about needing to find a new boyfriend?*

“Don’t you care?” she asked, and I wasn’t sure if she was asking about her own losses, or mine.

At a loss for words, I just shrugged.

“What is *wrong* with you?” she asked angrily, before standing up from the couch, and storming out of the room.

“I don’t know.”


# Chapter 55

**Victorina**

-----

So Quinn managed to spend a whole week hurting himself.

It started innocently enough of course, though Quinn’s attitude to the whole situation should have served to warn me that he was a little more reckless than the humans I was used to.

*At least Thera only tried to burn the clubhouse down just the once.*

It was late in the evening and I’d just finished going over some of the club’s books with Ken. We were relaxing in the sitting room, and Halea and Brandy had joined us as we enjoyed a quiet glass of wine. It was something of an oddity actually, as Brandy was usually very chatty, but she’d seemed much more pensive since watching Quinn’s movie about the thief with the magic suit. I found myself enjoying the relative silence, and while I didn’t dislike Brandy, I did find her constant chittering a little grating on the ears.

Our quiet revelry was interrupted though, by a dull thump from above, a muffled cry, and a loud crack from the balcony outside, and then another dull thump.

Halea glanced up at the window, and then to me, “Is it just me, or did anyone else hear someone fall off the roof just then?”

“Who would be stupid enough to be climbing around on the roof in the middle of the night?” I wondered aloud, as I set aside my goblet and walked to the balcony doors.

I heard a groan as I pushed the doors open, and peered out over the railing to see someone laying in a heap on the ground below.

“Quinn?” I exclaimed.

“Hi,” he groaned.

“What in the name of,” I muttered, “Hold on, I’ll be right down.”

“What the fext was he doing up there?” Halea asked, as I stepped back inside.

“How should I know,” I shrugged, “Come on, I think he’s hurt himself.”

“I’ll say,” she replied, as the two of us hurried out of the sitting room and down the stairs.

I cast Light as I stepped out into the grassy yard behind the clubhouse, an in the steady blue-white glow I saw Quinn still lying there, with one arm and one leg clearly very broken.

*Oh Quinn.*

“What in Weisse’s name were you thinking?” I asked softly, as I knelt down to better examine his injuries.

“Well that’s the thing,” he gasped, “It was Weisse that I wanted to get a better look at.”

“And you though the best way to do that was to throw yourself off the roof?” Halea half shouted at him.

“What? No! I wasn’t trying to kill myself,” he said through gritted teeth, “The planet, I wanted to get a better look at the planet.”

“Just hold still,” I told him, “And you, stop aggravating him and help me heal this.”

Halea grumbled something about being able to look at the “stupid planet” from the balcony, but helped me get Quinn put back together regardless.

“Are you alright?” I asked, as he got unsteadily to his feet.

“Yeah,” he groaned, flexing the hand of his previously broken arm.

“Are you going to explain just what it was you were doing now?” Halea asked.

“Yeah, just give me a second, I need to get my-“ he started.

I heard metal scraping on stone, and then something fell from the roof, to land with the sound of screeching metal and broken glass on the lawn beside us.

“-telescope,” he finished with a sigh, “Well, Neferoy won’t be happy.”

“And what is that meant to be?” I asked wryly, nodding towards the heap of twisted metal.

“That’s the telescope,” he replied, “Give me a moment to clean this up, and then I can explain what I was doing.”

------

Quinn joined us back upstairs a short time later, and I shifted over on the couch to make room for him. He took a seat beside me, and with no preamble, began his explanation.

“I’ve been doing a bit of reading-“ he started.

“You? No way,” Brandy teased.

“Hush, I’m talking smart people words right now,” Quinn chastised, “The point is, I read some about Weisse, as in the planet, and wanted to know more about it. The astronomy books I managed to find seemed more bothered about how watching the planets might predict the future, than about actually describing reality, so I decided to do some observations of my own.”

“And you think your observations will be any better than what elven astronomers have done over the course of hundreds of years?” I asked sceptically, “I don’t mean to insult you Quinn, I know you’re fiercely intelligent, but what are you going to know that they don’t?”

“Heliocentrism? It wasn’t until the fourteen or fifteen hundreds that Copernicus figured it out on earth,” Quinn said, “Elven astronomers seem to assume that some mystical force is behind the movement of the planets, since they can’t make sense of the way that they move. Which makes sense, because no one’s invented calculus, and no one’s figured out that the planet revolves around the sun, and not the other way around.”

“Wait. What?”

“Exactly. Throw that piece of information in there, and suddenly the movement of any given planet makes much more sense,” he said, as if that was supposed to make sense.

“That doesn’t make *any* sense at all Quinn, what are you on about?” Halea demanded.

“Quinn,” I started gently, “Now I know that you’re eyes aren’t the best, however…”

“It’s not a matter of whether my eyes are awful or not,” he said, starting to sound a bit irritated, “It’s a matter of fact. Give me a minute, I’ve got something on my phone for this…”

I looked up at Brandy as Quinn dug through the pocket library, “Do you know what he’s talking about?”

“Yeah, like, obviously,” she said, “The Earth goes around the Sun, its totes true.”

“Totes?” I asked.

“Totally,” she explained, “Like, super totally.”

“Here we go,” Quinn said, cutting off my next question for Brandy, “Take a look at this.”

I leaned in close to look at the window into the small tablet, and Halea leaned over the back of the sofa to peer at the images as well.

“This is Earth’s solar system,” he explained, “In the middle is the Sun. Its basically a big giant nuclear explosion that’s been going on for billions of years, and these are all the planets. This one here is Earth,” he indicated with one long and slender finger.

“That’s tiny,” I challenged, “And Solaris is barely larger than the moon. Maybe this is how it is on Earth, though I’m sceptical of even that, but it can’t be how it is here.”

“I promise you it’s true,” he said, “I should even be able to prove it mathematically once I’ve made enough observations.”

“And supposedly you’ll be able to better predict where the planets will be once you have?” Halea asked.

He nodded, “Yeah, should be easy.”

“Easy?” I asked, “Really? How far into the future could you make these predictions?”

“Into eternity. It wouldn’t matter how far in the future the prediction was, I’ll be able to do a year, as easily as a thousand years. And!” he said, seeing my incredulous expression, “I’ll be able to teach you how to do it.”

“Really,” I said flatly.

“Really,” he nodded.

“How?” Halea asked, “Because I feel like whatever you do might revolutionize Astrology. I can barely conceive of what the world would look like if you were able to so easily predict the future of someone’s life.”

“Well that’s the thing,” he said, “I’m pretty sure that Astrology, as a form of divination, is crap. That, or the spell is getting its answers from some second source, not directly from astronomic observations. Or maybe this world is driven entirely by fate, in which case I probably want to leave as soon as possible.”

I felt a slight pang in my chest at these words, “Leave? You find Fate that distasteful?” I asked.

“Freedom Victorina,” he said, “If my life is entirely predetermined, then I’ve got none at all.”

Halea shook her head, “Fate and Luck are powerful forces Quinn, but no one of the two wholly rules us all.”

“Well that’s some consolation I suppose,” he allowed.

“Are you going to explain the method you use to make your predictions then?” I asked.

“Calculus? Sure,” he nodded, “The confusion with Weisse aside, I should be able to show you how the observations in any given Astrology book would be transformed from the strange sort of figure-eight, to an ellipse.”

It took some time, and I don’t think any of us had managed to fully grasp what Quinn was explaining, but he did at least demonstrate how the ‘formula’ was used to make sense of the observations he’d collected from various texts.

“This is amazing,” Ken said, “I thought algebra was interesting, but this is something else entirely. It’s almost an entirely different way of doing arithmetic.”

Brandy, who had been sitting quietly on her own and sipping her wine, perked up at this. It was an odd sort of expression she wore, something between disgust and confusion.

“And your phone can do this in an instant?” I asked, “I can see how calculus alone would be a powerful tool when used with magic, spell design would be so much easier, but with the phone…”

Brandy rose, confusion and disgust turning to irritation and outrage.

“Yeah, calculus is amazing!” Halea agreed excitedly.

“No!” Brandy interrupted loudly, “No! This is wrong, this is all wrong!”

She pointed at Quinn angrily, who was clearly very confused, “You can’t just- It’s not- Arghh! Calculus- Calculus is *not* cool! You don’t get to have super hot girls pay attention to you because you know calculus, it’s *wrong,* that’s not how it *works,*” she said, with a stamp of her foot.

Quinn was grinning like an idiot by the end of her tirade, and he stretched contentedly as he leaned back, one of his arms falling to drape across my shoulders.

“Problem?” he asked.

“Ohmygod. I just hate everything, and this is so not fair,” she grumbled, before sitting on the floor infront of the table where the bottle of wine sat, to pour herself another rather full glass, “This whole place is upside down.”

“What about Weisse then?” Ken asked, dismissing Brandy’s complaints, “How does your fancy formula work there?”

“Well that’s the thing,” Quinn mused, “I can’t make sense of it. I’ve already run through the figures on all the planets, it’s how I know that Tupilaq is a gas giant for example, but Weisse is the only one that doesn’t make any sense. I have no idea how I’m supposed to plot its orbit. And what about the stuff I’ve read about Weisse causing tsunamis and other apocalyptic nonsense, is that true?”

Halea shrugged, “I suppose the tides are a little stronger than usual when Weisse draws near, especially when it’s eclipsed by the moon, but usually the major concern that most people have is the coming winter. That’s only possible every other cycle though.”

“Uh, what?” Quinn asked, blinking rapidly, “You’re telling me it’s not all some apocalyptic prophecy nonsense?”

“No, of course not,” Halea said, confused, like I was, by Quinn’s lack of knowledge, “Weisse draws near every two and a half years, the seasons change, and Weisse draws away.”

“You seem very confused,” I observed.

“I am very confused,” Quinn exclaimed, “What do you mean the seasons change?”

“Isn’t it like this on Earth?” Halea asked, frowning.

“Nope,” Quinn said, “I think I would have noticed, this doesn’t even make sense.”

“You were perfectly willing to drop all this heliocentrism business in our laps, but this is where you draw the line?” I asked flatly.

“Well…“ he sighed, “Just explain it to me, what is ‘the seasons change’ supposed to mean?”

“Weisse draws near on a two and a half year cycle. One cycle is warm, and the other cold. We’re nearing the end of the cold cycle. Weisse’s approach will signal the shift into the warm cycle.”

“That,” he paused, “That’s very unique. Just how much warmer will it get?”

“Spring and Autumn will be as Summer,” I explained, “Winter will be as Autumn, and the Summer will be even warmer.”

“And then two and a half years later, it all switches back to normal?” he asked distractedly, as he was busy scribbling notes on a sheaf of paper he’d pulled from his belt.

“Normal?” Ken piped up, “You think that Winter is normal?”

This gave Quinn pause, “Huh, well I guess elves wouldn’t see it that way. A whole lot of stuff is starting to make a whole lot more sense, elves’ issues with the cold for one.”

“What of Earth?” I asked, “It lacks any such cycle?”

“Nope, it’s seasons are pretty much always like this,” he said, waving vaguely out the window, “Winter, Spring, Summer, and Autumn.”

“And you two have no problem with that?” Ken asked, looking between Quinn and Brandy, who was still sitting on the floor.

“I’m from California,” Brandy replied in a slightly slurred voice, as if that had been answer enough.

“And I’m Canadian,” Quinn answered, as if that was also some sort of explanation, “I still have no idea how this cycle would be possible though. If Weisse was on a highly eccentric orbit, it might account for some sort of regular disruption, but if it’s been doing that since the formation of the solar system, then this planet would have been flung off into space, or thrown into the sun billions of years ago.”

“You know Quinn,” Halea said, her tone amused, “It is possible that your Outsider knowledge isn’t the answer to every problem. Maybe this is something that only the gods can know.”

“Yeah Quinn!” Brandy piped up, a little more loudly than was strictly necessary, and a little more slurred than before, “Maybe your calculist doesn’t work hu-year”

“Hmm,” Quinn considered, before discarding it as a possibility, “Nah, I’ll figure it out.”

---------

The next incident wasn’t quite as injurious as the mishap with the roof, but it did demonstrate Quinn’s general disregard for self-preservation.

I was just passing the clubhouse’s small laboratory, after retrieving something from my rooms, when I heard a thump like a body hitting the floor, and the clattering of furniture being knocked over.

I leapt through the door to the small room, a Fireball springing into each hand. I expected to see Quinn standing over a vanquished enemy, and assassin or kidnapper that had snuck into the clubhouse to do harm to myself or the others, and I was ready for a fight if the adversary had not come alone.

I need not have worried.

I did not burst through to see Quinn standing over an opponent, Quinn wasn’t standing at all. He lay sprawled on the floor, glasses askew, with a lump already forming on his forehead. A small crystal lay near his outstretched hand, and next to the table lay the tall stool he’d knocked over in his fall.

*Really, again?*

 I felt gingerly at his face and neck, making sure that he wasn’t hurt too badly, before picking up the crystal. It was a Manastone, with a single point of mana, and very freshly made.

*Well, I suppose that explains this mess.*

I sat down beside Quinn, and pulled him up into my lap while I waited for him to regain his strength. I cast a quick healing spell to banish the livid red lump he’d acquired in the fall, and brushed a few strands of hair away from his face.

That was the one oddity about Quinn, *well okay, maybe not the ‘one’ oddity,* he wore his hair much differently than any elf. He refused to let it grow out, and instead he regularly cut it short like a dwarf or gnome might. The beard though, that was not in the style of gnomes or dwarves at all. I knew that humans grew facial hair, but unlike those other races that could, he never let it show. Even Andrew and the other male humans wore some sort of goatee or beard, but Quinn shaved every day. Aside from everything else about him, it was a unique look, not quite elven, not quite human.

Eventually his eyes fluttered open, interrupting the contemplation of his features.

“Hi,” he groaned.

“You said that last time,” I told him lightly.

“At least this time I didn’t break anything,” he replied.

“And what have you learned?” I asked, adopting a lecturing tone.

“That even if I technically have just enough enervation for something, that doesn’t mean I should try to do it,” he recited tiredly.

“You know, you could have asked for help,” I told him softly, “You didn’t need to do it on your own.”

“Yeah,” he said quietly, “Still getting used to that I think. Thank you by the way.”

“Thank you?” I asked, raising an eyebrow.

“For all this,” he said, spreading his hands to either side, “If you hadn’t picked me up, I still would have found a club, but it wouldn’t have been like this. I’ve got friends now, because you gave me a chance. I’ve got more friends now than I ever had back on Earth. The help that all of you have given me, and the willingness you’ve got to listen to my inane ramblings… Well, I owe you a lot Victorina. Whatever happens between us, wherever this goes, I’m not ever going to forget that. Thank you.”

I looked down at him, laying there with his head resting in my lap. At the time I had considered it a favour to him, but only a minor one, I had after all gained nearly as much out of the deal as he had. But judging from his tone, and the intense look in his small green eyes, he didn’t see it that way. All this time it had meant something special to him, and I hadn’t even realized it.

“You’re welcome,” I replied simply.

“Well,” he said, closing his eyes, “I think I’ll just rest here for a bit, I’ve got an awfully comfy pillow. After all, you seem to object to me hurting myself,” he finished with a smile.

“Oh, you’re tired are you?” I asked in an amused tone.

“Exhausted,” he replied, “Using up all your enervation in one go really takes it out of a Mage.”

“So you’d like it if I gave you the chance to rest?” I asked innocently.

He opened one eye, and looked up at my wolfish smile, “So that’s where this is going?” he asked.

“Mmm hmm,” I nodded, slipping out from underneath him, and gently lowering his head to the stone floor, “Now you don’t go anywhere,” I told him, as I rose to my feet.

I went to the door, and poked my head out into the hallway for a quick check around. *The others should still be in class for a little while more.* Then I shut the door, and turned back to Quinn.

“Right here then?” he asked wryly.

“Yes,” I whispered hoarsely, as I unclasped my robes, and shrugged out of them.

They fell to the floor, and what little else I'd been wearing followed shortly afterwards.

Up till now I’d usually let Quinn do as he pleased when we were alone, and together. Sometimes it took a little prompting, or a little taunting, to get him to be as rough with me as I liked, but eventually he always let me have it. It was the one moment of weakness I allowed myself. It had been one of the first days we were properly ‘together’, when I got the wakeup call I’d needed. We’d both been wrapped up in the infatuation of a new relationship, and I hadn’t been thinking. We’d been sitting in the library, and I’d been watching him work, when Thera and Brandy interrupted us. What must they have thought? I’d been curled up in his hoodie, in his *clothes*, and practically wrapped around him. In the moments before they’d arrived, it had been bliss, cuddling with Quinn. Once they saw me though, I realized that it had been a mistake. Not the relationship with Quinn, certainly not, but they’d seen me, more vulnerable then than I’d ever been before. I couldn’t have that, and that had been the last time I’d been foolish enough to put myself in a position where I might be seen to be drawing on Quinn for strength or comfort. No more cuddling on the couch, and I was certainly not going to be seen wearing his clothes any more. If we showed any mutual affection when the others were present, it was a mutual display of strength. I certainly did not advertise my weaknesses.

But in bed? Well, then we couldn’t be observed could we? That was when I let it all out, and gods, it was satisfying. It was a dark and hungry sort of satisfaction, but it just felt so *good*. And even then, no matter what I goaded Quinn into doing to me, I knew that I was ultimately still in control, still safe.

Thera though had been a firm advocate, when she and I had found time for some girl talk, of the benefits of being on top, and now seemed like a perfect chance to explore her suggestions.

I pounced on Quinn, and tore at his clothes until his was naked on the cold stone floor below me.

“A little thirsty are we?” he taunted.

“Hush,” I rasped, before lifting myself up, and pressing myself back down onto him.

I arched my back as a shiver ran down my spine, and I felt his hands find my waist, though I could tell that he was still exhausted, there was barely any strength in those long fingers. I took things slowly at first, taking the time to savour the experience, and already I could tell that Thera had been right.

*Oh Verrin, is this what men get to feel? Suddenly I understand why men are such dogs, and why Halea is such a harlot.*

I leaned down to rested my elbows on his chest, and knotted my fingers in his hair, though he was big enough that I almost couldn’t reach. I planted a kiss in the middle of his chest, inhaling the smell of his body and licking at the sweat that was starting to bead on his chest. I found myself letting out small moans as I rocked back and forth on his hips and sucked at his chest.

“Like I said,” he said through a contented groan, “Thirsty.”

I would have drawn him into a kiss to silence his teasing, but with the difference in size, that wasn’t going to happen without some serious contortions. Instead I tried a different tack to silence him, and pressed myself the rest of the way down, grinding my hips against his. He let out a gasp, and a groan, and while that was a great deal quieter than I was being, I considered it an accomplishment. Quinn was a very quiet lover, and I’d found early on that any sort of vocalization meant that I was doing something *very* right.

And then someone opened the sarding front sarding door, and I froze.

“We’re back!” I heard Brandy call from the entryway.

Quinn, the bastard, did not freeze at the sound of potential visitors, and instead started rocking his hips underneath me.

“Quinn? Victorina?” she called, “We brought food home.”

“Quinn’s probably stomping around on the roof again,” Halea said, while Quinn continued to get me closer to what would be a rather noisy conclusion.

“Ww-hh-at if they c-come in h-here?” I hissed, as I tried my best to keep myself from letting out a whimpering moan, “And this r-room is not s-sound proof.”

“Come in here?” he asked, “Well I guess we better finish before that happens, unless you’re satisfied already.”

“That doesn’t seem terribly safe, someone really ought to talk to him,” came the sound of Ken’s voice.

“No,” I said, thumping one hand onto his chest, and clamping the other over my mouth to muffle the ensuing groan of pleasure.

I set my hands on Quinn’s chest, lifting myself up and letting myself down as quietly as possible. It was torture, trying to go quickly enough to reach a speedy conclusion, without going so fast that I started making embarrassing noises that might be overheard by our clubmates who were still bare yards away.

Quinn of course, seemed to be taking a sick sort of satisfaction in the whole situation. I was initially confused though, as he reached one exploratory hand between us. I was much less confused, once I realized what he was looking for, and he started teasing gently at it. I clamped one hand back over my mouth, and I felt my eyes start to water as I pounded on fist on Quinn’s chest repeatedly.

*Oh gods, they’re going to hear me.*

“What?” he whispered, as he continued the delicate finger work, “Is that not enough? You want more? Well, if you insist.”

I stopped pounding on Quinn’s chest, needing both hands to contain the sounds that I was making. My eyes were streaming with tears, and I kicked my feet against the ground as my back arched.

“You know Victorina,” Quinn said, though his voice was growing awfully husky, “You should get ready to cast Teleport, I’m pretty sure they’re going to hear you.”

I pulled my hands away from my mouth to snap out a retort, and it was precisely then that Quinn slipped a rather girthy manipulator into a very novel place. It was more than enough to make me lose control, and the beginning of a moan escaped my lips before I managed to clamp down on any further noise.

“Hey,” I heard Halea say, “I think one of them is working in the lab. Probably Quinn, you know what he’s like when he’s in the middle of something. He gets so deep into it that he barely notices anything that goes on around him. Minki, why don’t you go pull him out of whatever he’s pounding away at, the man needs to eat sometime.”

*Oh gods no.*

“Okay,” came Minki’s voice, quiet already, and muffled further by the hopefully thick enough door.

“Cast it,” Quinn said calmly, as I came down from the peak, still quivering uncontrollably, “Unless you want Minki to see this.”

“I am g-going to k-kill you Quinn,” I stammered out, as I fumbled through the gestures to the spell.

I had to retry them a second, and then a third time, before I finally managed to finish, and we were finally whisked away.

We landed in a heap on my bedroom floor, and I let myself drop bonelessly across his chest, as I tried my best to keep my lunch down.

“Well, that was close,” he said, “And, bonus, you didn’t throw up this time.”

“You are an awful and cruel man,” I said, as I rolled off of him, and lay to his side, “That could have gone terribly. What if they’d seen us there, in the- the middle of *that?*”

“Well, considering your robes and underwear are still strewn across the lab, they’ve probably figured it out already,” he said, and my blood ran cold.

“No!” I moaned, “Oh gods no!”

“Ah, I’m just fucking with you,” he said lightly, “I grabbed all of our stuff with my manipulators. That was actually right before I had the idea to see if the manipulator would fit in-"

I rolled over, and started drumming my fists on his chest until he finally shut up.

-----

It wasn’t until the third, *and the fourth,* incidents, that Quinn actually tried to burn down and knock over the clubhouse. Now those were a particularly interesting couple of days.


# Chapter 56

**Victorina**

-----

It was only after the third incident, that I really started to worry. I was aware that there were some differences between humans and elves, but it was only after my experiences with Quinn that I started to worry that humans might be a little more… relaxed, about self-preservation than elves. Leaping from the roof of a three story building had seemed at the time like the most that any one man could do to himself, but then Quinn was always full of surprises.

I was just casting my umbrella spell as I was getting ready to leave, when Halea leaned out from the balcony over the entranceway, “Hey Vic, where are you off too?” she called.

“The Library, why?” I responded.

I’d been planning to look into the politics of the former Ariros guild lands, I needed to know who our future vassals might be after all, and wasn’t really sure that I wanted anyone else along for such a trip. I trusted my clubmates as much as I trusted anyone, but I still hadn’t told any of them what Quinn had planned. Aside from it just being good practice, I didn’t want to get anyone’s hopes up.

She leaned back and glanced down the hall, before hurrying quietly to the stairs, and down the steps.

“I was thinking that we should take a look at what maps and charts there are of the land north of the city,” she said quietly.

*Dammit Quinn, have you told _everyone_ what you’re planning?*

“Why exactly?” I asked, dreading the answer.

“Well Quinn can help enchant manastones now, I figured that we ought to get some proper base stones to enchant,” she said, still keeping her voice low.

*Crisis averted, if briefly. However…*

“Then why do you want to go poking around in the Library for maps?” I asked with furrowed brows, “If you want to pick up the stones then get Ken to write you a letter of credit from the club and take it down to a jeweller. And why are you whispering?”

“The jeweller is too expensive,” she said dismissively, “Any gemstone good enough to make a properly large manastone is going to be really expensive. So that leaves two options, and one of them is going to be way more fun than the other.”

“Oh? And I’m guessing that your *fun* alternative is something that Ken would object strenuously too?”

“Exactly,” she whispered back, “We could try to find someone that’s still got some high quality crystals that would work, *or…*”

“We do something horrifically dangerous to steal some?” I asked wryly, “If you’re so worried about cost, just wait until you can buy the crystals like everyone else does.”

“Hey, find, not steal. It’s not stealing if no one owns it,” she insisted, “And I don’t want to wait around like everyone else does, exactly because it is what everyone else does. Good crystals cost nearly as much as the gemstones do, and they all get snatched up within hours of being brought into the city.”

“Alright, fine,” I acquiesced, “What’s the alternative?”

“Well Quinn had been badgering me about the cursed guildhall, you know how curious he can get,” she explained, *yes, yes I do,* “And between that and your story about Quinn’s first attempt at manastone, I was reminded of something that I’d come across in passing, oh, it must have been a year ago.”

“I’m listening,” I prompted.

“Well supposedly, and this was before everything went tits up at the guild, the Ariros Mages were starting to look into what resources might be found under those mountains. Well one of the things they found was…” she prompted.

“Crystal?” I guessed.

“Crystal,” she nodded, “A lot of it, a whole lot of it.”

“Halea…” I said gently, “That was-“

“A thousand years ago,” she agreed, “I know, but I think it can still work. I know that pretty much any idiot thrill seeker will have picked the guildhall itself clean, but I think the mine should be fine. Its days and days north of here, in the foothills of the mountains, and probably not many other people know of it any more. And everyone’s heard all about how everything north of the city is a monster infested deathtrap. Almost no one that knows of or knew of the mine is going to go take that risk, not when they’d be traipsing about the foothills looking for something that they’re not even sure is there. And no one that didn’t already know is going to bother going that far just to look for some loot.”

“The more you tell me about this idea, the worse it sounds,” I told her.

“Well, it’s only a terrible idea if we don’t know where the mine is,” she said confidently, “And I know exactly where it is.”

“Really?” I asked, quite surprised.

“Sort of?” she hedged, “I managed to find someone else’s notes, I don’t know whose, but they detail the Mage’s exploration of the Library. One of the things that he came across was some of the old, old records for each of the guilds.”

“So you know where to find records that may or may not exist, that may or may not include maps and charts, that may or may not show where the mine is.”

“Yes.”

“And this is all also assuming that the mine hasn’t since caved in, flooded, or that it was even dug in the first place.”

“Yes.”

I sighed, “Fine, come on.”

-----

It was some sort of miracle, but we found those damn maps. They were exactly where Halea’s little notebook had said they would be.

“Well, what now?” Halea asked, as we looked down at the thick vellum map that when rolled out, covered the entirety of the massive table before us.

“Why are you asking me? You were the one who insisted we come looking for this.”

“Why am I asking you? You’re the leader of the club!” she insisted, and in fairness, she was right, “So what’s the plan?”

“Do you really want to rush off north on thousand year old information?” I asked sceptically.

“It does sound rather foolish when you put it that way, but who else would have been there to loot the place? And even if it has caved in or flooded a bit, I bet that wouldn’t be too much of a problem,” she said earnestly.

“I suppose,” I allowed, “With some earth moving spells, and some way of dealing with any flooding… That does still leave the issue of whatever creatures inhabit the forest though.”

“So we bring along Neferoy and Quinn. Neferoy’ll jump at the chance for cheap manastones, and I don’t think anyone needs to tell *you* how good Quinn is in a fight. We don’t even need to walk or ride most of the way. It’s not like the whole of the guild’s lands are deserted, there’s still some villages near the borders with the neighbouring guilds.”

“So we’d just teleport as far north as we could manage, and then cut in east to head for the mine?” I asked, nodding towards the mark on the map.

“Exactly, we’d get more than half way there before we even needed to worry about what we might run into in the forest.”

“Well then,” I said, “Let’s go back and ask Quinn. We’ll also want him to take an image of this map with his little Outsider contraption as well, I’d rather not need to take the time to copy all this.”

*And I imagine he’ll be interested in what else there is here.*

------

One of the windows to the clubhouse was broken when we returned, and thick white smoke was billowing out of it.

“Is that the lab?” Halea asked.

“Yes,” I said through gritted teeth.

“Huh, I wonder what Quinn’s been up to?”

“You seem very relaxed about the clubhouse being on fire,” I said, as I quickened my pace.

“Oh, it just looks like a small fire, I’m sure Quinn’s fine.”

“We’ll see what I can do about that.”

----

I stepped out of the entryway, around the corner into the hall, to see Quinn sitting in the middle of the hall in front of the door. He looked exhausted, his face was covered in soot, and I was sure that he’d had two eyebrows last time I’d seen him.

“Quinn!” I growled, pointing an angry finger at him.

“Oh, hey Victorina,” he said, turning and giving me a big stupid grin, the stark whiteness of his teeth contrasting strongly with his soot blackened face, “Don’t worry, the fire’s out, and I’m fine. Just waiting for the smoke to clear.”

“What in the name of all that is sacred were you doing?” I demanded, “And how did whatever you were doing break and window and light the lab on fire?”

“Oh, I was experimenting with different black powder mixes. I’m pretty sure I managed to figure out the best mix too,” he explained, seemingly oblivious of my displeasure, “As for the window and the fire, well maybe I didn’t think things through all the way.”

“You?” Halea said, “Nooo, I can’t believe that.”

“Quiet you,” he said, waving dismissively, “There was some probably some particulate matter left in the air, and I forgot that not all of the clubhouse’s lights are magical. It must have caught on one of the candles on the wall by the door. Well that set of the powder on the bench in front of me, and that blew out the window and lit some stuff on fire. Nothing important though,” he added hurriedly, “And I’ll pay for the window.”

I turned to Halea, “Do we still…”

“Yes,” Halea insisted, “See, if this proves anything, it’s that Quinn is courageous enough that he’s willing to take risks when he thinks it’s necessary.”

“Courageous?” I asked, “I don’t think that’s the word that first comes to mind.”

“What are we talking about here?” Quinn asked, from his place on the floor.

I sighed, “Go ahead and tell him.”

------

Quinn had loved the idea of course, and promised to have something useful to show of his experimentation with black powder for the trip. I was a little hesitant to encourage his fascination with pyrotechnics, but I didn’t think that he was about to stop what he was doing any time soon. Instead I banished Quinn’s future experiments with pyrotechnics to the back garden, and gathered the rest of our adventuring party in the library to plan our trip.

Thera came by just a little later, poking her head in to say hello, though I saw that she was carrying a rather sizeable package along with her.

“Hey, has anyone seen Quinn?” I’ve got the stuff he wanted me to make,” she said, hefting the package.

“He’s out back,” I replied absently, and had intended to get back to working with the others, when I had a terrible thought.

*Oh dear Weisse, is that package full of more of that black powder?*

“Hold on!” I called, just before she closed the door.

She pushed it back open a bit, “Yes?” she asked expectantly.

“Just what is it you’ve made for him?

“This?” she asked, adjusting her grip, “It’s something Quinn called mercury fulminate. He said it was really important, and that I had to make absolutely sure that no one else heard of it, and especially that they didn’t find out how it was made.”

“Not black powder then?”

She shook her head, “What’s that?”

“Quinn’s new way of destroying the clubhouse,” I said wryly, “He can explain it better, he’s out back working on the stuff.”

“Well,” she said with a smile as she shut the door, “Maybe he needs a hand.”

“Oh don’t worry,” Neferoy said, having noticed my expression as Thera left, “Quinn’s clever enough to avoid any *big* mistakes, and the most he’ll end up doing out in the garden is scorching a few trees.”

“Yeah Victorina,” Halea said with a grin, “What’s the worst that could happen?”

-----


# Chapter 57

**Quinn**

-----

The back yard of the clubhouse wasn’t terribly huge, but being in the middle of the city meant that space was at a premium, and so I guessed that something like this would still be considered quite the luxury. With a short stone wall ringing the yard, and the large pine trees planted along the wall, the yard was rather well screened from the sights and sounds of the city beyond. Which suited me just fine, I didn’t want any prying eyes to see just what it was I was doing.

What was I doing? Well I was revolutionizing warfare in Elardia, that’s what I was doing. There was really only one piece missing, and that was…

“Hey Quinn,” Thera called, as if on cue, ”I’ve got your stuff for you.”

I turned away from my work, to see her shouldering her way through the clubhouse’s back door, carrying a rather bulky package in both hands.

“Thanks, and it even looks like you’ve still got all of your fingers, I’m impressed.”

“Were you expecting me to lose some fingers along the way?” she asked, raising an eyebrow.

“Wasn’t sure, mostly it was going to come down to how closely you followed my instructions,” I replied.

“Well you’ll be glad to know that I followed them to the letter, your demonstration of just what this stuff could do was pretty eye opening,” she said, as she set down the package on the table and took a seat, “Is this what wars are fought with on Earth?”

“This specifically? Well not exactly. There’s more advanced primers in use now, and even back when this stuff was used, it wasn’t the main focus. No, that was black powder.”

“Right, isn’t that what you used to blow up the lab?” she asked sweetly.

“That,” I said, raising one finger sternly, “Was an accident.”

“If you say so,” she teased, “What are these things?” she asked, pointing to the future of warfare on Elardia.

“That’s the future of warfare on Elardia,” I replied.

She sighed, and gave me an irritated look.

“They’re rifles,” I explained, “This one here on the left is a matchlock, maybe you’ve heard about the weapons my Uncle is making for Nezzabi?” I asked, and she nodded, “Well that’s what this is. Same design, except better made, since I can cast Reshape, and have a few specialized tools enchanted with the spell. That’s how I did the rifling for example.”

“Rifling?”

“See here?” I asked, casting Light to shine down the barrel, “Grooves cut into the metal of the barrel, it makes the projectile spin. It doesn’t work the same as fletching on an arrow, but it serves the same purpose.”

“So your Uncles weapons are the… rifle? Equivalent of a bow that shoots arrows without any fletching?”

“Exactly,” I smiled, “Which means already my weapons are better than his.”

She rolled her eyes, “Continue, what about the other ones?”

“This one is a wheel lock, and this one is a flint lock. They both work on more or less the same principle,” I explained, “Which is that instead of having a bit of slow match burning to carry the flame, they use a piece of flint striking against a bit of metal.”

“They don’t look much different than the match lock,” she noted.

“And they’re not, really the only difference is the lock system. They all use loose powder, take ages to reload, and aside from the wheel lock won’t always fire reliably,” I explained, “And even then, the wheel lock is the most delicate of the three, and the most complicated to make. If I hadn’t had a lighter to pull apart, it would have taken much longer to make this, even without Reshape.”

“How is the mercury fulminate supposed to work with these ones then?” she asked.

“Well that’s the thing, it doesn’t. It’s only once you get to the next stage in firearms development that it has a use,” I said, picking up another one of my rifles, “This is where it starts to matter. You’ll notice that there’s no flint on the end of this rifle’s hammer.”

“I’m guessing that the hammer is supposed to whack a bit of the fulminate, and that sets off the powder?”

“You’ve got it,” I nodded, “But the thing is, once you’ve got the tech for mercury fulminate and cap and ball revolvers, you’re pretty much all the way to fixed ammo.”

“Fixed ammo?”

“Like this,” I explained, picking up one of the few brass cartridges I’d been able to make, “It’s a little more complex than just using loose powder, but it’s much much faster. Even with this rifle here,” I said, indicating the cap and ball rifle, “You’re pretty much assembling your ammo from scratch, every time you need to fire the gun. With this though,” I waggled the brass cartridge, “It’s all one piece. The fulminate is here at the back, the brass is full of powder, and the projectile goes at the end.”

“And just how powerful would this be then?” she asked, “Is it any better than a bow?”

“That is a very good question,” I said, setting the weapon aside, “Even with the cap and ball rifle, that’s the one there by the way, you could make the argument that a bow is better. It’s faster, you don’t need to worry about the powder getting wet, and it’s just generally far less complicated. Especially since if it came down to it, a soldier could make their own arrows, but not their own powder. But once you start talking about fixed ammo, the bow is unquestionably inferior.”

“Why though,” she challenged, “Even with the ‘fixed ammo’ as you call it, how is that going to be any faster than a bow? You’ve still got to put the bullet in each time you want to fire, and it still has all those other troubles that you just mentioned.”

“If I was going to settle for single shot rifles, maybe,” I allowed, “And it would be a *big* maybe. One thing to consider is how difficult it is to train someone on a bow, compared to what it takes for a gun. A bow takes years of training to be able to do properly. A gun though, you can train someone sufficiently on a gun in a couple of weeks if you’re really strapped for time. It’s not ideal, especially since elves live longer and aren’t quite as plentiful as humans, but being able to turn every able bodied person into an effective soldier on a couple weeks’ notice is pretty useful.”

“I think that the lords and nobles try to do that anyway,” she said, “Even if it just ends with a lot of people dying most of the time.”

“Well, I doubt that any of these weapons is going to cut down on the number of people dying,” I grimaced, “But it's certainly going to make a big difference in just who’s dying. Especially when you consider this last rifle on the table.”

I hefted the rifle, and drew back the bolt.

“I might have skipped a few designs in between cap and ball, and bolt action rifles, but once I got the proper Reshape tooling, this wasn’t very hard at all to build.”

“Why is this so special?” she asked, peering into the action of the gun.

I pulled the tab on the back of the magazine, and pulled it free, “See this?”

She looked confused, but nodded.

“It holds ten cartridges, takes three or four seconds to switch out, and as long as the magazine has got more rounds in it, you can fire the rifle as fast as you can work the action,” I explained.

“Oh,” she said, “*Oh.* That… Well I imagine that changes things quite a bit.”

“Just a little,” I agreed, “I still need to test them, since I haven’t had any fulminate of my own to work with, but I suppose that issue’s dealt with now.”

“Is this going to be enough to test with?” Thera asked, “I didn’t make very much.”

“Well let’s get this unwrapped and take a look, but you’d be surprised at how little I’ll need.”

The package was mostly a big bundle of cotton padding, with some small pouches of the powdered fulminate spread throughout. It wasn’t a lot, maybe a hundred grams in total, but that was plenty for my needs.

“Yeah Thera, this is perfect. I’ve got enough here for fifty or a hundred rounds of ammunition.”

“Are you going to be doing that much testing?” Thera asked, “That seems like a lot.”

I shrugged, “Maybe. I’ll want to proof all of these guns, and figure out the point of aim for the bolt action rifle, which might mean I go through all of the fulminate you’ve made.”

“Well now that I’ve got it all figured out, it wouldn’t be too hard for me to make more, Quinn. What are you going to do with all this once you’ve tested it though?” she asked, “Are you planning on sharing what you’ve made?”

*Hell no.*

“I’ve got some plans, but I’m not going to go looking for a patron just yet. Besides, all of these are made with brass receivers and brass barrels. I’d like to be using steel barrels, and I’ve still got some more improvements to make, so they’re not quite as ready as I’d like them to be yet.”

“Steel?” Thera asked, eyebrow raised.

“Like iron, except better,” I explained, “Of course, it’s more complicated than that, but it gives the general idea.”

“Well what about these brass guns then?” she asked, looking back to the table, “Are they any good?”

“More or less, I mean even the matchlock is better than anything my Uncle’s made, but it’s all a bit heavier than I’d like. And it’s not going to be strong enough to stand up to smokeless powder, whenever I get that made. Right now though, each individual shot will be a little weaker than a low powered Magic Missle, which isn’t too bad for something that requires no enchantment at all.”

“Smokeless powder? You can make it burn without any smoke?”

“Not quite, just a lot less smoke. It’s actually something I wanted to ask you about, since I’m going to need a couple different acids to make it work. If I’ve got those acids though, I won’t need you to procure smelly sulphur and saltpetre for me.”

“Just flesh melting acid.”

“Exactly,” I said cheerily.

“Can’t you just cast Acid Jet or whatever else you Mages use to maim each other?” she asked, "Then you wouldn’t need to bother purchasing it at all."

“I’d thought that would work, and that was actually the first thing I tried. The trouble is that the acid disappears after a minute or so, and if I was just trying to melt something, then that wouldn’t be any problem at all. The trouble is, the acid reacts with the other reagents, forming a compound of the different ingredients. So when the acid dissipates a minute or so later, most of the rest of the compound goes along with it.”

“Well then, if I get you the acid you’ll be able to make this…”

“White powder,” I supplied.

“White powder then,” she nodded, “Why didn’t you start with this stuff anyway, instead of messing around with the black powder? I’m going to have a much easier time getting the acid, than the other materials, especially since you’re adamant that I be all secretive about it. No one’s going to bat an eye if I go procuring batches of acid for a Mage’s club, not like they would have if they found out about the other materials.”

“My phone wasn’t working at first, and I hadn’t had time to dig through all my old text books. I had some vague idea of how guncotton is made, but it’s terribly unstable. One of my Military History textbooks though went over the transition period between black and smokeless powders, and actually includes the formula for the early French efforts in the area.”

“Whatever,” she shrugged, “Am I going to borrow one of your belt pouches again, or can I just order this normally and have them drop it off at the clubhouse?”

“Actually,” I said, reaching into one of my entirely mundane pockets, “I’ve got a present for you.”

“It’s a purse,” she noted.

“A *magic* purse,” I insisted, “See here, it’s got the same enchantment as my belt.”

“Quinn that’s…” she started, “This must have been *really* expensive. Um, isn’t…”

“Isn’t what?” I asked.

“Isn’t Victorina going to be a little miffed that you’re showering some other woman in gifts?”

“It’s not a shower,” I said defensively, “It’s one gift. And besides, it’s barely even a gift. Think of it more as a bribe.”

“A bribe?” she asked wryly.

“Exactly, a bribe. Can’t have you going off and telling everyone about my secret plans.”

“Secret plans? Am I going to have an important place in your new administration?”

“I dunno, I’ll have to ask Victorina how she feels about me taking concubines.”

“Concubines?” she laughed, “You do have big plans for the future.”

“Very big,” I nodded, and she rolled her eyes.

“Just how are things between the two of you then?”

“Pretty good?”

“You say that like you’re not sure,” she observed.

“I just don’t really have a good point of comparison,” I said honestly, “This has lasted longer than any other relationship I’ve been in.”

“Hold on a minute,” she said, turning her head to one side, “What about that week with me in Myra?”

“What about it?” I asked, trying to keep my face from flushing.

“Oh my gods,” she said, eyes widening, “Was that the first time you were ever with a w-“

“Alright! Enough already,” I interrupted, “No it wasn’t the first time.”

“Are you sure?” she asked with a grin, “You’re turning pretty pink.”

“It might have been the first time that lasted more than a minute,” I grumbled quietly.

“Oh Quinn,” she howled, “You are just so precious!”

“Go away,” I said petulantly, “Or you’ll not get any more bribes from me.”

“You know,” she said, putting a finger to her lips, “This explains so much about you.”

“I hate you so much right now.”

-----

Thera’s comments, even if they were rather embarrassing, did give me something to think about once she’d finally left. It had been just about a month since the incident after the ball, and I hadn’t been exaggerating when I’d told Thera that was the longest any relationship had lasted. As far as I could tell though, it was going pretty well. There were some hiccups of course, and the cultural differences between elves and humans had started to show themselves a little, but the two of us were happy with each other’s company. There had been a minor shift, after those first couple days, when she’d given me back my hoodie. Up till then she’d barely taken the thing off, even sleeping in it once or twice. Somehow, despite Victorina being a literal princess, it had given her a sort of girl next door quality. With her silver hair all bunched up in the hood, and the huge blue-grey eyes, she’d looked… Not normal exactly, the eyes threw that off, but she seemed softer and less lethal.

That wasn’t to say that I wanted someone who was small and vulnerable or that I was looking for someone to protect, but as it was now, I did find myself feeling like I needed to be ‘on’ all the time. It wasn’t quite as extreme as when we’d gone to the ball, or when I was in class, but I found that I couldn’t relax quite as much around lethal Victorina as I could with hoodie Victorina. Now that was not to say that I was about to jump ship, because good god damn, Victorina is amazing both in body and mind. I did miss the softer and more approachable Victorina of the first couple days, but having a girlfriend that was also a total badass had benefits of its own.

*Who knows? Maybe this is exactly what I need to get over some of my awkwardness.*

-----

I managed to get a set of runic symbols made that same afternoon, a little after my talk with Thera. In anticipation of Thera delivering the mercury fulminate, I’d been experimenting with the magical creation of steel for use in the construction of my new guns. It was harder than I initially thought it would be, since it was a bit more complex than just adding more heat. I managed to figure it out eventually though, and the process consisted mainly of forming a furnace with Apportation to contain the heat and only then casting the Heat spell itself. I didn’t get a whole lot of steel, and it wasn’t a very high grade of steel since I hadn’t added oxygen and carbon quite properly, but it had been enough for me to create several small tablets to inscribe the runic symbols.

The book I was teaching myself from had explained how to go about creating your own set of symbols, and had said that while you could have someone else make a set for you, it was almost always better to do it yourself. It was entirely possible to have a master goldsmith create a set from precious metals, and that would grant some benefit to the symbol caster, but even then it was only a marginal increase in effectiveness over an amateur crafting the symbols for themselves.

It was that night, sitting on the edge of the bed, that I tried symbol divination for the first time.

*So, just how is it going to work out between Victorina and I then?*

I cast the spell, my question firmly in mind, and reached into the pouch where I kept my symbols.

---
**ᛋᛠᚠ**
---

*Hmm.*

“What’s this then?” Victorina asked, rolling over to lay on her belly next to me, sideways across the bed.

“I’ve wanted to experiment with divination for a while now. I want to see if I can get a good idea of just how accurate it really is,” I explained, “No idea what this is supposed to mean though.”

“Does it say ‘put away your toys, and sard the beautiful woman lying next to you?’” she asked.

“No actually.”

“Well it’s what I’m saying,” she said, as she rolled over and stretched languidly.

“Well if I must,” I sighed.

----

**Quinn**

----

My dreams that night were *quite* interesting, and featured not one, but four Victorina’s. Each of which seemed particularly interested in maximizing my personal enjoyment, and I was slightly disappointed when I woke up and there was just the one gorgeous and naked woman in bed with me.

And there was another thing that gave me hope for the future, or at least for a future that included Victorina and I together. I found that I slept better when she was around. I’d only had two bad dreams when she was present, one of which she’d even personally interceded in.

*That’s something I’ll need to explore, I wonder what else you could do with dream magic. Could I use it to study while asleep? Now there’s an idea…*

The rest of the time it was much like what I’d just experienced. I didn’t always remember my dreams, but they were always pleasant and those I did remember tended to feature Victorina in some capacity, even when my dreams weren’t specifically sexual in nature. Sometimes it was something absolutely mundane, like the two of us taking a walk, going to the store, or eating together.

*Could be my subconscious is trying to tell me something. Maybe I should try to pick up some oneiromancy next time I’ve got the chance.*

It was only on those occasions that we slept separately, that I found it hard to sleep through the night. I found myself waking up after having strange and disjointed dreams, usually involving water, and missing the solid warmth of Victorina’s body curled up against me.

“Sleep well?” Victorina asked through a yawn, as she pulled herself up to rest her chin on my chest.

“Yeah,” I replied sleepily, “Any plans for this morning?” I asked, as I let one hand drift down her side.

“Unfortunately, I’ve got quite a bit of club business to take care of today,” she said, as she brushed my hand away, just as it was getting to the interesting bits, “But if you can wash up and get dressed quickly we can go to breakfast together before I’ve got to rush off.”

“I suppose that will have to do for now,” I said reluctantly.

“Be quick about it then,” she replied, before casting a spell and teleporting herself across the hall to her own room.

It didn’t take long at all to shave, wash, and dress, and I found myself waiting for several minutes for Victorina to get herself ready. It was raining again, which seemed to be the norm for Nimre in the Autumn, not that I minded. I liked the sound the rain made on the shingles of the clay roof, and on the glass of the windows. I liked the musty earthy smell of rain, but most of all, I appreciated how the rain would bring with it a wave of cool air. I’d take a massive thunderstorm that ripped branches loose with only the force of the wind, or that blasted trees to charred splinters, if it just meant that it wasn’t going to be hot today.

*Man, this eternal summer stuff is going to suck. Could Weisse do me a favour and just stay the hell away?*

“Ready to go Quinn?” Victorina called, as she stepped into the front hall.

“Yeah, can you do that umbrella thing? It’s pouring rain out there.”

She nodded, as she ran through the hand gestures for her spell,

“Anywhere in particular you’d like to go?” she asked.

I shook my head, “Anywhere is fine, I figured you’d want to find somewhere close to your errand for this morning.”

“That’s probably for the best, come on, I know a nice place.”

I followed her out the door, and into the din of the crashing rain, doing my best to stay close to her to shelter under the field she’d created to keep off the rain.

“Quinn,” she started, once we’d walked for a bit, “Do you think you can get some camping supplies together in time for Louday? I was thinking that if the weather is going to keep this up,” she said, waving vaguely at the sky, “I’d rather go earlier into the autumn, rather than later. Besides, I imagine you might find the manastones useful for whatever it is you’re planning to do?”

“Louday? Yeah, do we want to leave right at the start of next week though? I can probably get away with it, I’m ahead in my classes, but what about the rest of you?”

“I can manage, and Neferoy and Halea assure me they’ll be fine. We’d end up cutting into a couple days of classes anyways, and I’d rather arrange it so that we return when we’ve got a day off so we’ve got a chance to rest before going back to classes. You might have finagled things so that you’ve got three days off each week, but the rest of us only get the one.”

I shrugged, “Works for me, anything in particular we’ll need?”

“Um, well just use your judgement I suppose.”

I raised an eyebrow and looked down at her, “Use my judgement?”

“I’m a sarding princess, how often do you think I go camping? You’re the expert, make Ken write you a letter of credit, and go get whatever we’ll need.”

“As you wish,” I said wryly.

“Now that’s better,” she said haughtily, “Now here’s the place, do your best to look respectable and not like a giant, wilds dwelling, barbarian.”

----

I didn’t actually need to do a whole lot of shopping to get ready for the camping trip, since I already had enough camping supplies tucked away in my Portable Hole for two people, and enough food for several times that. So my shopping trip mainly consisted of restocking what food I’d already gone through, and purchasing the raw materials I’d need to make several more hammocks. I was originally only going to bother making another two, but if I was going to buy the materials and get all my tools out, it wouldn’t be that much more work to make a bunch more. So I made eleven, which on top of the two I already had, meant that I had one for each member of the club, plus a spare. It was probably overkill, especially since I also now had thirteen thick blankets tucked away in there, but it would mean that if worst came to worst, we could bug out on a moment’s notice and already be completely prepared.

*I have no idea what sort of monumental shit storm it would take to cause the entire club to need to flee, but I’m ready if it happens.*

I also made sure that my new bolt action rifle was in working order, and stowed that along with two full mags in a separate belt pouch entirely. Twenty rounds wasn’t a lot, but it was what I had enough fulminate for after all my testing, and it was probably a lot more than anyone else would have. It wasn’t ideal, since an antimagic field would still cut off my access to it, as it was in an extra dimensional space, but it would do for now. In the long term, hopefully once I got smokeless powder figured out, I’d make a couple of revolvers or a short barrelled shotgun and use the Shrink enchantment to carry it around. That would need to wait though, until I’d done a little more testing with the enchantment, or modified it to suit my needs.  

There was a light knock on the door, which drew me forcibly out of my work, and just after came a little mousey voice, “Quinn?”

I turned to see Minki clutching the door frame, almost hiding behind it. Her shoulder length dark grey hair had been straightened a month or so ago, when she’d been forced by her parents to attend the ball, but I could see that it was starting to return to the tangled mess that was its ground state. I only saw one big grey eye and a bit of her face, but the bit that I did see had turned a little pink, embarrassed at needing to intrude like this.

“Yeah Minki?” I asked.

“Were you maybe thinking about making dinner for tonight?” she asked quietly, “I-It’s getting late, but Kennocha hasn’t gone and ordered any food yet.”

“Sure,” I said with a smile, “Was there anything in particular you had in mind?”

She shook her head, causing her grey hair to fly everywhere, “Whatever works best for you,” she said in a small voice, “But… I would really like it if there was cheese.”

“Cheese?”

She nodded vigorously, and there was more flying hair, “I really like cheese. Pizza is really the best thing ever, and the burgers too, when you put cheese on them, and ham and cheese sandwiches, and there was that time you made the rice with the cheese sauce. I really liked that.”

“Cheese,” I mused, “Hmm, I think I can work with that. It’s not going to be terribly fancy though, not what I have in mind.”

“What do you have in mind?” she asked, and finally she poked her head out the rest of the way, embarrassment giving way to curiosity.

“Grilled cheese,” I proclaimed, and Minki’s eyes lit up.

“W-well if Victorina doesn’t think it’s princessly enough for her, then she can take it up with m-me,” she said confidently, though the intermittent stutter might have detracted a bit from the firm tone.

“If that’s the case then,” I said, standing up and lunging towards her, “Then you can be my little helper as I get dinner ready,” she tried to dodge away, letting out a shriek of laughter, but I caught her. I scooped her up and tossed her over my shoulder, carrying her down the hall and up the stairs to the kitchen, Minki wriggling and giggling the whole way.

----

I set her down on the kitchen counter, and she brushed at her hair, which had fallen to cover her eyes in our trek from the lab.

“So what am I supposed to be doing?” she asked, as I pulled what I’d need out of the cupboards.

“It’s really simple,” I explained, “I’ll show you how to make it, so next time you want a cheesy snack and I’m not around you’ll be able to put something together.”

She pulled a little notebook out of her robes, and set to writing down each of my instructions. It being grilled cheese, it wasn’t terribly complicated, and we found ourselves waiting for the sandwiches to finish grilling.

“Minki,” I asked, “You’re probably the best one to ask about this, but do we have any books on dream magic in the library here?”

“I think so,” she started, before turning absolutely beet red, “Um! I t-think that Halea has a whole bunch of really, um, special, sorts of dream magic books. But if you want the normal stuff, I think Victorina knows better than I do. She’s been really studying a whole lot of dream magic stuff recently.”

“Oh yeah?”

*Oh fuck.*

“Yeah, though I’m pretty sure borrowed Halea’s, um, special books, on the subject too. I’ve seen her reading in the Library, or in the sitting room. Why?”

“Oh, I was just wondering if it would be possible to use dream magic to train or study.”

She nodded, and I managed to avoid going any further down the rabbit hole that was this conversation, only by distracting her with the now cooked sandwiches. It was a big hit actually, and even the rather regal Victorina appreciated the ‘human food’. Minki in particular loved the sandwiches, and somehow, despite being all of four and a half feet tall, managed to wolf down four of the things.

I had quite a bit to think about afterwards, as I was carrying Minki’s tiny form off to bed, the little elf already deep into a food coma.

*If Victorina was able to come into that first dream… then what the hell about the others? Would she do that? Wouldn’t I be able to resist it? I’m supposed to have a greater Will than even other humans, but I have no idea if that would work while I was asleep. I feel like I should be able to sense when someone is casting spells on me, even when asleep, but maybe that’s why the bedrooms of the clubhouse are so heavily enchanted? Would she do that though? What would there really be to gain? Fuck. I know what there is to gain. If dream magic can do what I think it can, you could mess with someone on a subconscious level. You’d be able to train them like you could train a fucking dog, but the rewards and punishments would come on a subconscious level. The subject wouldn’t even know that they were being rewarded or punished, but that positive or negative reinforcement wouldn’t be any less effective than if it was being done on a conscious level. Hell, it was probably more effective to do it this way.*

There was a big question then, and that was what I was supposed to do about it. I cared a whole hell of a lot for Victorina, and I hoped that she did too, but what if she didn’t? What if the whole nympho girlfriend routine was an attempt to control what she saw only as an asset? She was a princess, and one from Adympia no less, maybe I trusted her too much.

*Is that all it takes to stop me from thinking clearly? For someone to wave a pretty woman in front of my face? Fuck, I’m no better now than I was when I first arrived here in Elardia. Sila, Chypia, Thera, and Victorina. It’s entirely possible that I’m terrible at this. For fuck’s sake, Thera’s the most innocent of all of them, if that word can even be used to describe her. Yes, I was a means to an ends for her, but I’m pretty sure we both knew what that end was going to be when we first started. For Sila I was a way out of a bad situation, for Chypia I was a trophy with knowledge of advanced weapons, and for Victorina… Dammit, for all I know, she views me the same way that Chypia did. Worse still, I had to go and blab about my plan to lift the curse.*

And Chypia… when I’d first arrived in Essens I’d made note of the fact that elves seemed rather more trusting than I would have expected comparable humans to be, and I’d carried that forwards to my experiences with Chypia. She had after all given me leave to explore the city after only a week or two in her hands, and I’d chalked that up to the naïve sort of trust that elves seemed to display. But that need not be the case, in fact, it probably wasn’t the case. If anyone here was naïve and overly trusting, it sure as hell didn’t seem to be the elves. So what if I’d violated Chypia’s trust? As far as she’d known, the city was a prison of its own, one that I’d still been trapped inside. It was only because the harbour defences accounted only for elven level endurance that I was even able to escape in the first place. From her perspective, the ‘trust’ had cost her nothing, but had hopefully gained her the trust of the slaves she was working to gain control of.

*The illusion of freedom, without the actual possibility of it, late night swimming adventures aside.*

That readjusted my perspectives a little.

*Just a little.*

Had I seen Diova acting particularly trusting? Had I seen that from anyone in the club? From Lili? From any of my teachers or class mates? I’d dropped into an idyllic peasant village, and assumed that it had been the same there, as everywhere, but that made no sense. Was a nobleman going to show the same naiveté as some ill-educated farmer? Was the royal daughter of an emperor going to be quite as naive as the peasant daughter of an innkeeper?

*No, of course not Quinn, you colossal fucking idiot.*

----

Needless to say, I did not sleep in Victorina’s room that night. I tried to pay careful attention to my dreams, hoping to notice if there was any tampering, but I couldn’t remember any of what I’d experienced come morning. I didn’t sleep very well, but that went without saying. For all I knew, I was a day or two from discovering a heart wrenching betrayal. I didn’t want to confront her though, not now, and not on non-existent evidence. It hurt like hell just to think about it, because dammit, I really cared for her. But I had to know more before I went and put myself out on a limb again.

I spent the whole of that day in the University Library, reading what there was to read on dreaming magic, and on how spells would work on sleeping subjects. I found essentially what I’d expected to find. Firstly, I found that dream magic was a wide enough field of study that anything I’d experienced in the past month had been entirely within her capabilities, assuming she bothered to learn the right spells. And secondly, a sleeping or otherwise unconscious subject would automatically resist any spell cast against them, this was one of the many reasons that for it being so difficult to heal someone that was grievously wounded. If they passed out from their injuries, you’d be trying to push through their natural defences. Of course unless the subject was a Mage, Wizard, or specially trained, those defences were non-existent, but it could still cause difficulties with something as delicate as healing magic. The only exception was when the subject trusted the caster unconditionally, in which case their spells could get through. But that was the trouble, because it was binary. Either you didn’t trust completely, and didn’t let their spells through, or you did trust completely, and did let their spells through. There was no discrimination between the types of spells. Once you let them in, you let in *whatever* they might decide to cast.

*Do I trust Victorina that much? Am I foolish enough to do that? Yes and yes.*

The test then was simple. I was pretty sure that I now no longer trusted her unconditionally. That meant that all I needed to do, was hop back into bed with her. Either she wouldn’t cast the spell, and all would be almost as it was, though something small but important had been lost, or she would cast the spell, and in resisting it, I would wake immediately.

*I really hope I’m wrong.*

-----

**Continued in comments**


# Chapter 58

**Quinn**

-----

We rose before dawn the following morning, and despite the events of the evening prior, I found that I was well rested. I slipped out of Victorina’s room soon after waking, as I wanted to avoid getting caught by a Victorina that might still be feeling some effects of the potion she’d taken the night before.

*Still don’t know how I feel about that, can’t any of my relationships just be normal?*

My preparations for the trip didn’t take very long since most of what I needed was already tucked away in various extra dimensional spaces, so after doing a brief check to make sure that all was still in order I made my way to the kitchen to prepare a proper breakfast. It didn’t take long for the smell of bacon, eggs, and pancakes wafting through the clubhouse to draw in the others, and soon we were all seated around the island in the kitchen.

It was quite the interesting collection of travelling companions, and not exactly what I imagined when I thought of an adventuring party. There was Neferoy, and like Minki she was about four and a half feet tall, though the dwarf was significantly stockier. Her robes were grey silk with black trim, though she had a thick travelling cloak thrown over them to keep off the rain that was still hammering against the windows. Compared to the others her brown hair was short, falling only to her ears in several thick braids. Dwarves, like elves, had oddly huge eyes, and Neferoy’s were the sort of yellow-orange colour that reminded me of an owl. Her skin was pale, though in a slightly unhealthy and sun-deprived way, very unlike the milky white perfection that Halea and Victorina had cultivated. She had squarish features and a prominent nose, which would not have been an attractive combination for a human, but as a dwarf it gave her a dignified presence. Of all of us, Neferoy actually looked like the one that would be most at home on some sort of treasure seeking adventure. The rest of us? Not so much.

Halea, for one, looked like a supermodel. She’d also added a thick wool traveling cloak to her gold robes, but rather than detract from her attractiveness, it just looked absurd. She was slightly above average height, which for an elf woman meant that she was about five feet tall. To say she was slim would be to do her a disservice, because while she didn’t have an ounce of excess fat, the word ‘slim’ might give one the idea that she was somehow narrow in hips and bust. This was very much not the case. Narrow in the waist, very much yes, but her flared hips and very generous bust strained the limits of what was possible. Which did make a lot of sense, now that I knew that Halea’s body from the neck down had been the work of an expensive enchantment. I wasn’t quite sure how much of her face had been the work of similar reconstructive magic, but it lacked the excessive form that the rest of her form seemed to have, so I guessed that it was at least mostly her original face. Like all elves she was sharply featured, with cheekbones you could cut yourself on, and a fine jaw that came to a delicate point. She had night black hair that fell in ringlets to her shoulders, and her huge eyes were a deep violet. Taken together with her skill at battle magic, I was reminded of Yennefer from the Witcher video games.

Victorina shared Halea’s general supermodel like qualities, but where Halea was excessive, Victorina was reserved and elegant. She also wore her normal mage robes under a traveling cloak, and while they were purple which would mark her as someone of rank wherever we went, between the falling rain and the cloak it would be hard to pick out the particular colour once we were out of doors. We were of course still clearly a bunch of Mages up to no good, but at least the purple of Victorina’s robes wouldn’t catch the light like Halea’s gold robes would. She was taller than Halea by several inches, which at about five foot four, meant that she was as tall as even the tallest male elves. Victorina too, had an amazing figure, but it was not quite as extreme as Halea’s. I guessed that it was still the product of some magical modifications, but it somehow seemed more carefully done.
