I rolled my eyes at the last comment, and told him, “Halea’s going to teleport over and pick me up, I’ll be fine.”

He leaned back, “Good, good. Just don’t work yourself to death. I would not have held it against you if you’d requested we join you in your own clubhouse to get this finished.”

“Hmm, well that’s not a terrible idea actually. But I’m pretty sure Victorina would not be a fan. It's fine Diova, I can get Halea to play taxi.”

“How you ever managed to get a Ducal princess to play servant for you I’ll never understand,” he said with a shake of his head, as he stood to leave.

---

“Hey, wake up you big dolt,” Halea said, as she shook me gently awake, “Pretty sure that last time you let yourself fall asleep like this it did not go well. Come on, wake up.”

“I’m up, I’m up,” I protested, pushing my glasses up my face and rubbing at my eyes.

She helped me up, and steadied me when I risked teetering right over, “Whoa there Quinn, are you alright?”

“No, I got bitten by a vampire and she drank all my blood,” I said wryly, “Just get me back to the clubhouse so I can lay the hell down.”

“Mmm, sounds good to me,” she smouldered.

---

# Chapter 71

**Quinn**

---

The following day’s battlemagic class was waived in favour of letting the teams prepare for the coming melees, and we made sure to take full advantage. The rules had been set out in such a way that only magical skill and tactical aptitude were going to matter. We’d all be wearing robes made specifically for the arena, which meant that unlike the standard tournaments, we’d all be on level ground when it came to armouring or defensive enchantments. It was the same with any sort of enchanted item actually, we either couldn’t bring them at all, or if we did, as was the case with Mages who used staves or wands, they would be ones issued by the professors. Which meant that we needed to have a damn good idea of just how we were going to approach this whole mess.

“There’s four teams, including ours, so... What, each team fights three matches, and whoever wins the most is the best team?” I asked.

We’d met in the Library this time, at the top of one of its many towers. It was the same tower I’d stood in while planning my break in to the Forbidden Tower actually, and I couldn’t help but glance across to it every now and then. The space was bare, other than the furniture we sat in, and there was little cover for those that might try to overhear us. Countering magical observation was left to Isal and Setisi.

“Basically,” Isal confirmed, “Though there might also be a tiebreaker if it’s necessary.”

“Why don’t you just teach us all Magic Missile?” Myli, the one that made Sila seem mature, asked, “Then we could beat them really easy, just like how Halea won the tournament!”

I shook my head, “Not an option, I have an agreement with another party at the University. I sold the rights, with the condition that neither of us distribute it for an entire year.”

“Oh,” Myli said sadly.

“Besides all six of us throwing the same spell over and over, no matter how powerful it is, is not a good strategy. Magic Missile is amazing, but it has its limits, and someone could still get the drop on you. No, we need to be playing to our strengths and covering each other's weaknesses.”

“Why don’t we go around the room then?” Setisi, the little red brown gnome, asked, “And each of us says a little bit about what we can do well, and what we need some help with.”

“The human can go first,” Isal said, prodding me under the table with her foot.

I raised an eyebrow, but did as I was bade, “I’m good at dealing out damage, especially at very long range, but I’m not great at defensive magic. I mean, I *know* the spells, but that doesn’t really mean a whole lot. I can cast a shield if I need too I guess.”

“Didn’t you kill all those kidnappers?” Nina asked.

“Sure,” I shrugged, “But they were shooting at me with bows, and my robes were enchanted. It wasn’t much of a contest, but even then, I went down the first time they managed to hit me somewhere the robes didn’t cover.”

“Well I might be able to keep you covered there,” Isal provided, “I’m not much good at offence, it’s like you said, I know the spells but it doesn’t mean much. Defensive magic I can do though.”

“I’m okay at both kinda, I guess,” Nina hedged, “I like Jet spells though, I don’t know about the other stuff though. My best might only be as good as your worst,” she finished, nodding towards Isal and I.

“Hmmm, I think we can work with that,” I mused, as a plan started to form.

“I’m where Nina is basically,” Setisi said, “The two of us have been working on Jets a lot, so that’s about all we’ve got for fighting magic. I am pretty good with illusions though.”

“I don’t know,” Myli said hesitantly, when it became her turn, “I don’t think I’ve really got any strengths, I’m only really here because Isal made me come.”

“*Myli*,” Isal groaned.

“It’s fine,” I assured them, “We can work with it. What about you Sila?” I asked, looking at Sila, who had not spoken this whole time.

She’d spent our entire conversation sitting as far from me as possible, and staring at the surface of the table the whole time.

“Sila?” Isal prompted, after Sila didn’t respond.

“Fine,” Sila sighed, “I can cast defensive magic well enough to protect myself really well, or myself and one other person. I can’t do Jets like you two can,” she nodded at the others, “But I’m much better when I can keep my distance or surprise someone.”

*I wonder what you could do with a skill set like that?*

“Well, is the big strong man going to tell us all what to do?” Isal asked, giving me a knowing look, “Oh spit it out,” she demanded, after I cocked an eyebrow at her.

“It’s a simple plan,” I explained, “Isal and I stay in the centre, and she shields everyone-”

“Everyone?” Isal asked, surprised, “I haven’t got that kind of mana, Quinn, not if you want the shield to last more than thirty seconds.”

“You don’t need to worry about that,” I said, shaking my head, “I’ll cover the energy costs, you just try to use it as efficiently as possible.”

“Oh...” Isal said thoughtfully, “That could work, damn, yeah, that could really work.”

“Same goes for Setisi,” I continued, “The rest of you would be arranged in a square around us, and Setisi would be one of the front corners. At the start of a fight she keeps us covered, and I keep her provided for mana. Not for too long I hope,” I said, glancing to her, “But I should be able to keep it up long enough for us to get into a good position while we’re still under cover of your illusions.”

Setisi nodded, “I can do that, you wouldn’t even need to provide all of the mana, just some of it and I’d be able to keep it up for several minutes at least.”

“Perfect,” I smiled, “Well once it starts your job would become much simpler. You and Nina, who would be covering the other front corner, would use those Jets to keep any of our opponents from getting in too close. Sila and Myli would cover the rear two corners, and between the three of us we’d deal with anyone out of range of your Jets.”

“Do you really think this can work?” Isal asked, “And you’re sure you can afford to give up that much mana? Are you even going to be able to cast Magic Missile while you’re playing mule for the rest of us?”

“Well hopefully we won’t have the illusion and the shield going at the same time,” I explained, “But yeah, I can do it, and still cast Magic Missile. To give you a frame of reference, almost every time you’ve seen it used in the Arena, it was being cast at a level I can do for free.”

“Oh,” Setisi breathed.

“Yeah,” I nodded, smirking a little, “And more than that, I have a hunch, and if I’m right, it’s going to win us our first match no matter how badly we mess up the plan.”

“That’s rather confident of you,” Isal said skeptically.

“Confident,” I agreed, “But not *over*confident, and for one simple reason. The others are all going to try to do the lone wolf thing. Our first match is going to be a series of six, six on one fights. *Maybe* six on two, if they managed to figure out what’s happening before we get to them all. It's only after that first fight that we’re even going to need to worry about locking horns with the whole enemy team at the same time.”

Isal tilted her head from side to side as she rubbed at her chin, “I don’t think that’s as sure a thing as you seem to think it is, but I do think you’re pretty close to the mark. It would be a safe bet to say that most plans the others will come up with will begin with ‘we all split up’. They’re probably going to rush off to try to get kills before their teammates ‘steal’ them. Fext, even after the first match, they might still try splitting up to fight us.”

“So we might win then?” Myli asked, almost jumping up and down with excitement.

“Yeah, I think we might,” Isal smiled.

---

It was quite a bit later, just as the sun had gone down on that same day, that I found myself alone with Mata. We’d finished and handed in Solar Pulse a little after lunch, and already it was being distributed throughout the University. By the same time next week every Mage in the University would have unfettered access to the greatest anti-vampire spell ever created.

*You’re welcome entire world.*

“Stop looking at me like that,” Mata demanded, though her hugely plump lips made it hard to understand her sometimes.

“Like what exactly?” I asked tiredly.

*I really hope I can recover a least a bit by next week, I’ll be no good if I’m always feeling this fatigued.*

“Like that,” she repeated, as best she could, “All the women look at me like I’m a sarding whore, and all the men look at me like they want to sard me stupid. But you look at me like I’m something to pity.”

I didn’t really have much to say in response to that, I mean, she was right. She might have been overstating the feelings of the other students, either in magnitude or volume, but she wasn’t wrong, not in essence.

I leaned back in the chair, and stared up at the ceiling, “Why?” I asked simply.

“Why’d I let Diova turn me into a doll he can dress up in pretty clothes?” she snapped.

“Yeah,” I said sadly.

I saw, out of the corner of my eye, as she turned her face away from me, “Because I don’t like dressing like the peasant that I am, because the money I get helps so many people back home, and because I love him.”

“***What?***” I exclaimed, snapping awake, and sitting bolt upright in the overstuffed armchair.

“Is it that hard to believe?” she asked, “Even before I got to the University and started sending my bursary back home, Diova would always send money to the village. And then, once I did get here he offered to let me join his club. I knew what he wanted from me, but living there was one less drachm I had to spend on housing, and one more drachm I could send home. And it’s not like I hated the idea,” she said, turning bright red, “He’s a prince, a *prince*, and he wanted me, even as I used to look. And the more I got to know him, and the more I spent time with him, the more...” she let out a long breath and hesitated before continuing, but did continue, “So when he asked me if I’d agree to take shape changing enchantments and potions, I said yes. He could have given those to anyone, but he gave them to me. If this is what ‘perfect’ looks like to him, then I’m happy to be *his* perfect.”

“And everyone else?” I asked.

“I don’t like it,” she said, “How they look at me, but it doesn’t matter, not really.”

*And I thought my love life was fucked up.*

-----



# Chapter 72

**Quinn**

---

“For today’s lesson we’re going to cover something I’m sure most of you have been waiting for,” the professor explained as he set down a rather large bundle on his desk, “And that’s magical foci.”

This made even the regularly lazy students straighten a little in their seats, and the professor unwrapped the bundle to show a collection of wands and staves which ranged from six inches to five feet in length.

“We’ve spoken about these a little already, but it’s about time that everyone learns how to make one of these for themselves,” the professor continued, “Each of these is a ‘blank’ and you can pick any one you like to use as a base for your new wand or staff. You can also provide one of your own if you’d prefer something other than what I have here.”

“Does it need to be made of wood?” one of my classmates asked, “Or can we make it out of anything we like?”

“The majority of the focus must be organic,” the professor answered, “However you may add non-organic materials to it, such as metallic end caps, or mana stones.”

“What do you mean by majority?” I asked, “The majority by weight? Or is it by volume? Could I get a dagger proportioned in such a way that the wood and leather of the hilt is a large enough portion of the dagger to make the whole thing an acceptable focus, even with a metallic blade?”

The professor nodded appreciatively, “That is a good question Quinn, I’m not sure. My guess would be that it is by weight, but I couldn’t really say for sure. Though in the specific example of the dagger you would not want to include the leather of the grip in the casting of the foci enchantment. The enchantment would fall apart the first time you needed to replace the grip.”

“What does a Mage need with a dagger anyway Quinn? Any proper Mage wouldn’t be forced to resort to such barbaric measures,” one of my classmates taunted.

“What counts as organic?” I asked, ignoring the comment, “Is charcoal organic?”

“Obviously,” the same student snorted, “I thought Outsiders were supposed to know things.”

“Do I know you?” I asked, turning to the giant knob in gold robes, “Because I think I’ve seen your slightly stunned face elsewhere, but I can’t quite place it.”

“Gentlemen...” our professor warned.

“You saw me yesterday you idiot, I guess humans really are blind,” the Mage said, “I’m Olar, son of Duke Sulia, and you’d better treat me with respect.”

*Oh.*

“Yeah, that made you sit up and take notice didn’t it, you’re a lot quieter now that you know just who it is you’re talking to.”

“Oh shut up,” I said tiredly, “Is charcoal organic as far as foci are concerned?” I clarified, as I dismissed Olar and turned back to the professor.

“Yes,” the professor nodded, as he spared a tired glance for Olar, “Though such a focus would be rather fragile, not to mention messy.”

One of the other students, not Olar this time, piped up, “What about mana stones? You said we could put those in a focus?”

“Ah, now you’re getting to the heart of the matter,” the professor said, as he picked up one of the stave length blanks, “For most of you, or even all of you, a normal focus doesn’t offer a whole lot. You might use it as a status symbol, or a badge of rank, but it doesn’t add a whole lot to your spellcasting. Wizards or less talented Mages will often see a significant increase in their spell’s power or effectiveness when they use a focus, but most of you are naturally talented enough that the difference is negligible. Mishaps will be slightly less common if you use a focus for your spellcasting, but there comes a point where it’s more of a hassle to be carrying your focus around. Unless of course you modify your focus to do more than simply focus your spells.”

“What, so we just pile on a bunch of spell enchantments?” Olar asked, “Firebolt, Lightning Bolt, Teleport and stuff?”

“Essentially,” the professor explained, “Where a Wizard might have a collection of purchased wands, each to cast a spell that he doesn’t himself know, you would have a single wand able to cast multiple spells with more mana than you’d normally have access to.”

“How is that any different from just casting it yourself and using a manastone?” the professor was asked.

“Another good question, why indeed? It’s a matter of how a manastone is used by the wand or staff. A manastone embedded in an item of any sort, whether that be a focus, a magic sword, or a suit of armour, is able to provide its power much more efficiently than a loose manastone. It comes down to one of two options. Either you may attach the stone as a so called ‘dedicated’ manastone, which effectively doubles the amount of mana the stone provides, or you may opt for an ‘exclusive’ manastone which *triples* the mana provided.”

“Triple?” I asked.

*Could I use this to enchant the spellstone? Or even dispel the stasis enchantment? Could I replace the manastone with a bloodstone and turn one soul into three thousand mana?*

“Yes triple,” he agreed, “Though there are limits. In both cases the manastone is only accessible by enchantments cast on the item itself. Consider the following,” he said, holding the blank staff up for all to see, “Imagine that I’ve placed two enchantments upon this staff. The first is the enchantment to turn this into a proper focus, and the second is one that would allow anyone with magical talent to use this staff to cast Firebolt, regardless of whether they knew the spell themselves or not.”

“So it would be like one of the wands of Firebolt you can pick up at one of the shops in town?” I asked.

“Exactly,” he nodded, “Now imagine I attach a dedicated manastone. This manastone is a one point manastone, but as part of the staff it would provide two mana. Now if someone picks this up they’ve got two extra mana with which to cast Firebolt, but not anything else. I could use this staff to focus my casting of Lightning Bolt for example, but I wouldn’t then be able to access the energy in the stone. If I wanted to be able to do that, I’d need to enchant this staff with Lightning Bolt as well.”

“What about enchanting enchantments then?” I asked.

“Enchanting enchantments?” the professor asked.

“Could I enchant a staff or wand to enchant other things, and then do the whole dedicated manastone thing to get more juice for enchanting?” I asked.

“Juice?” he asked with an amused tone, “No, while that would make enchanting a great deal easier, it’s not possible.”

*Damn.*

“Disappointed?”

“Yeah,” I grumbled.

“Perhaps you’ll find some other Outsider trick to apply to enchanting, but I don’t believe that this is such a case,” he went on, “Enchanting isn’t just much more complex than spellcasting, but it also takes a conscious mind. Trust me Quinn, your trick has been tried.”

*Note to self, create magical AI.*

“Alright, now where was I?”

“Dedicated and exclusive stones?” someone asked, “What’s the difference?”

“Ah yes, a dedicated stone is simply a stone that is only accessible by the item it’s attached to. It offers twice as much mana and recharges twice as quickly as well. When using the wand, staff, sword, or what have you, you can draw power from the stone, yourself, other stones you might be carrying, or any combination thereof. And yes, this is the only way to bypass the one manastone limit. An exclusive stone is a different in only two areas. First, as I’ve already mentioned, it is even more efficient. Second, if you include an exclusive stone as part of an item it becomes impossible to provide energy for its enchantments with external sources. Now depending on just what spells you’re planning on enchanting the wand with that might not be too limiting, but it is something to keep in mind at least.”

“Does an exclusive stone also recharge at triple the normal rate?” I asked.

The professor nodded, “Yes, and you touch on an important distinction. A dedicated or exclusive stone does not suddenly become capable of storing two or three times the normal amount of energy, the actual energy contained within remains the same. The enchantments are simply better able to use that same power, so we observe it as an effective two or three fold increase.”

“Just how does the regeneration happen?” I continued, “A normal manastone recharged at a rate of one every twenty four hours, does an exclusive stone recharge three every twenty four, or one every eight hours?”

“What’s the difference?” Olar snorted.

“Too subtle for you to recognize,” I snapped.

“That’s enough,” the professor chided, “And yes, it’s one every eight. The stones recharge gradually over time.”

“What about-” I started.

“Enough Quinn, I am pleased that you take such interest in enchanting, but I must go on, if you have more questions you may ask them after class,” he said in an amused tone, “Now, back to the matter at hand. Over the next several weeks we’re going to work as a group to create a basic focus for each of you, so you’ll want to come up with a solid idea of just what you want placed on the wands or staves you select. You may add whatever you like in your own time, but for the portions of the process that will include your classmates everyone will be limited to two enchantments, beyond the initial casting of Focus.”

We spent the rest of the class learning how to actually cast Focus, until about eleven when the professor called an end to things and we broke for lunch. I glanced at the desk on my way out, but left the blanks where they were. I had a better idea.

*Time to find Nothus.*

---

“You’re shorter than last time,” I said, by way of greeting, as I joined her in our usual spot in the Library.

“You said that last time,” she noted.

“And you were *also* shorter last time,” I insisted, “You’re not that much taller than Victorina now.”

She shrugged, “I don’t need to be a giant to be super strong any more so I’m moving to a size that’s a little more convenient,” she explained, and again I felt like it wasn’t the whole truth, “Now, what do you want?”

If I’d been a little more self centred, or perhaps a little more starved for feminine attention, I would have assumed that she was making the change for my benefit, but that didn’t seem to be the case. She was shorter now, about five foot six, but she hadn’t become any more obviously feminine. She had cut down a little on the excessive bulk, but most people who didn’t know her would still confuse her for a man. Not just because of her overly plain features, but also because of her skeletal structure. Hand her X-Rays to a doctor and they’d probably conclude from the hips, chest, and waist, that she was male. Yes, she was shrinking, but it wasn’t for my benefit. But why the shiftiness then? If she really was downsizing for convenience, why change the subject whenever it’s mentioned?

“Who says I want anything?” I asked defensively.

She didn’t say anything, but glanced up and gave me a wry look.

“Fine, fine, I wanted to know if you can make more of those carbon nanotubes I showed you.”

“Of course I can make more,” she frowned, “I’m doing it now to reinforce my bones, it’ll be another couple of days before its all finished.”

“I meant with a spell, could you create it like you did with the adrenaline?” I asked, “Or even transmute it from charcoal?”

She shook her head, “No, I didn’t bother to create a spell for it. We could,” she offered, “If you wanted to, just like we wrote up the spell to create the adrenaline, but it would take a while, and even once the spell was done we wouldn’t be able to create a lot of it. Not quickly at least, since we’d be creating only a few grams at a time. How much of it do you need?” She asked.

“Enough for a wand,” I sighed.

“That would take... I don’t know, months? Even transmutation wouldn’t make it that much quicker.”

“What about your bones?” I asked, “That hasn’t taken you months.”

“That’s different,” she explained, “And it’s not magic. Transmutation magic could do it almost instantly, and wouldn’t take much more energy than the two of us could provide, but we’d need to invent the spell from whole cloth. We’d need to define the starting material, end material, and every step in between. It’s not as simple as inventing *Transmute to X*, we’d need to invent *Transmute X to Y*. I can do it more quickly because... well, I just can. If I could find some way to make a spell work the same way my shape-shifting does then I’d do it, but I wouldn’t even know where to begin.”

“Damn.”

“We could still do it,” she offered, “I’d love to have a wand like that, it would just take several months.”

“I suppose, for now I might just need to pick up one of those blanks then.”

“Learning how to make your own foci?” she asked.

“Yeah.”

“Hmm, maybe I can make my shape-shifting work for this,” she mused, looking up at me out of the corner of her eye, “You’d owe me one though.”

“Owe you *one*?” I laughed, “Pretty sure I owe you more than one. Minki’s life, my life, my hands...”

“You’ll be able to add your eyes to the list as soon as I can figure out how to heal something that isn’t actually damaged,” she said dismissively, “But I’ll let you pay me in advance for the wand thing.”

“Name it.”

As if on cue, her stomach rumbled loudly, “*FOOD!*”

---

Did she lead me to her favourite restaurant, or a cafe perhaps? No, no she didn’t. When we finally came to a halt, it was outside a butcher’s shop. What did she order you ask?

A fucking side of beef.

Now you might be wondering, “Quinn, just what is a side of beef, isn’t that some cut of steak?”

And I would say no, it’s not any *cut* at all, it’s *all* the cuts. A side of beef is half of a fucking cow.

At least she let me cook it first.

I’d dropped the thing into my Portable Hole and we’d teleported north of the city to set up a damn big campfire. Better to make a mess out in the woods than somewhere in town, and I doubted that Victorina would like the idea of Nothus tearing into the massive hunk of meat in the basement of the clubhouse.

At first I had wondered just where she was going to put it all, but then I noticed the changes. As I watched her devour it all with fascination and horror I saw her muscles become better defined, and her shoulders broadened. Her height too had increased, and by the time she finished her meal she was back to her old self, as she’d been when I’d met her for the first time in healing class.

*That was fast, and her robes kept up with her as she grew, interesting...*

“Give me a day or two,” she yawned, as she stretched out contentedly next to the fire, “And I’ll have a proper wand blank for you.”

“Are you sure you’ve had enough to eat?” I asked, as I kicked at the wreckage of her meal. “I don’t know, maybe you need a little bit more material to work with to make the wand.”

“Oh hush.”

I took a seat on a convenient tree stump, and let out a deep breath. For all I preferred computers and a tidy indoor existence, I enjoyed being outside like this. I was content, and not just in this moment, but in general. Coming to Elardia had been the greatest thing to ever happen to me, yes it had been hard, and I’d been through more in the past several months than most people on Earth went through in a lifetime, but every bit of it was worth it. I’d finally found something that I had true passion for, I had power, money, and I got to have sex with absolutely gorgeous women *really* frequently, which might have been the best part of the whole ‘Outsider’ deal.

*It’s almost like the Olympic village on steroids. A whole city full of people who are as young and beautiful as they want to be, and each one with essentially no consequences for doing as they please. Hell, even if I weren’t an Outsider I bet my luck would be pretty good.*

My self congratulatory back patting was interrupted a little while later by an odd skittering sound in the woods, and I leapt to my feet.

“What is it?” Nothus yawned, barely bothering to stir.

“Something out there,” I whispered, “Probably drawn by the smell,” I said, nodding towards the pile of bones.

Nothus pushed herself up reluctantly, and had a look around, “Can’t see much of anything,” she said quietly, “It’s getting dark, and the forest is pretty thick here.”

“I thought you’d have super eyes,” I whispered back.

“How would I know how to make super eyes?” she hissed.

“I’ll explain after, for now...” there was another skittering sound, and this time I was ready for it.

I thrust my hand forwards to cast Solar Pulse, and I was immediately greeted with three bright flashes and a muffled thud.

Nothus picked herself up off the ground finally, and covered me as I stepped forwards to investigate our attacker.

*Well technically they didn’t attack us, but if Solar Pulse took them down...*

“A ghoul,” I said once I finally made out the shape on the ground just outside of the clearing, “Not a vampire.”

“Either way, we should get back to the University. If we’re running into ghouls this early in the evening they’ve got to be nesting nearby, we ought to let someone know.”

“Alright, do you have somewhere specific you want to be or am I going to do the teleport back?”

“Go ahead,” she said, and I put a hand on her shoulder, and we were gone.

---

“More ghouls?” Halea asked, as she leaned against my desk.

I’d teleported Nothus and I back to the clubhouse’s beacon, and she’d promised to let someone know about the ghouls and then left, before I could reiterate my offer to have her join the club. It was a little while later now, well after the dinner I’d made for myself and the others, and Halea had joined me in my room as we started to wind down for bed.

“Just the one,” I said, “Though there were probably more about. The Guard has been notified, they’ll handle it.”

“Thanks for that by the way,” she said quietly.

“Letting the Guard know? That was Nothus actually.”

“No you big gibbering idiot, not one ghoul you ran across in the forest, the cave. You saved Minki, and *everyone* loves you for that, but you saved me too. There are other healers, but I don’t know anyone else who could have fixed what that ghoul did to me. I probably would have lost my foot if not for you.”

“You’re welcome?” I guessed.

She rolled her eyes, “This is the part where you come over here and take advantage of my gratitude.”

I closed the distance to her quickly, pulling my shirt up and over my head as I did. She shrugged out of her robe and let it drop to the ground in a puddle of silk, revealing that she’d been wearing nothing underneath, and moved as if to meet me halfway. I pushed her back gently with a quickly cast spell, and her rump thumped against the edge of the desk.

I stepped in close, and she reached up, slipping her arms around my neck. She got up on tiptoe to kiss me, and as she did I grabbed her by the back of her thighs, lifting her onto the desk. I kicked out of my loose trousers, and pushed her away gently but firmly until her back was pressed against the cold hard wood of the desk.

She wrapped her legs around me, drawing me in deeply, and I was given a very *firm* reminder of just how strong elves really were. I ran my fingers down her bare stomach, appreciating the strength hidden beneath her soft seeming exterior. I drew my hands down until they rested lightly on her hips, and took a moment to drink her in.

“Are you going to ogle me or sard me,” she taunted, tightening her legs around me.

I took a firm hold of her hips with both hands and set to it, while she thrashed, arched her back, pulled at her hair, and said the most unladylike things.

---
---
---

Despite Halea’s best efforts, I managed to get a good night’s sleep, and she woke me in her usual fashion in time for me to get a proper breakfast before heading off to the last enchanting class of that week.

“I’m not going to bother you for very long,” the professor explained as the lecture started, “I’m sure you’d all like time to plan out your new foci, and some of you still need time to learn the spells. So I’ll try to keep this quick. What I’ll be covering today are meta and linking enchantments, essentially enchantments that control how and when other enchantments are active or inactive. They’re also fairly cheap to cast, and each of you should actually have the energy to cast it multiple times without assistance. There are multiple versions of the spell, but the concept is simple. You set a criteria, as broad or narrow as you like, and if it is met, your instructions to the item or enchantment are carried out. You may also give instructions for what should happen when your criteria are not met, or if alternative criteria are met.

*If then, else if, else...*

“Professor!” One of my classmates whined, “Quinn’s laughing again!”

---

“What the fuck is that?” I asked incredulously, as I stepped into the little reading nook where the re-biggified Nothus was lounging.

“What does it look like?” she asked smugly.

“It looks like a fucking *femur!*” I exclaimed.

She shrugged, “Yeah?”

“It’s black!”

“You wanted a focus made of carbon nanotubes,” she said simply, “Well there you are.”

“Is that *your* femur?”

“Obviously.”

*Oh for fucks sake.*



# Chapter 73

**Quinn**


---


“You’re a fucking lunatic.”


“And?”


I just shook my head, “Is this the only one, or did you do both legs?”


“This is the only one,” she said, “Oh, did you want another...” she said, as she started reaching for her thigh.


“No! Holy fuck Nothus! That’s not what-”


She laughed, “I’m just sarding with you Quinn, relax.”


I sighed, “Did you replace it at least?”


“Well I managed to make it up the stairs, so I think so,” she told me sarcastically, “Is this going to do the trick then?”


“I think so,” I said, picking the femur up gingerly.


It was incredibly light, and if I hadn’t known better I might have assumed that it was a Styrofoam model. It was a little over half a metre in length, and three or so centimetres in diameter. Theoretically I could Reshape the upper and lower extremities, turning the large knobby bits into more length to make a staff, but that seemed pointless. I needed a focus, but not one so large. A Wizard might get more use out of a staff than he would with a wand, but for a Mage at my level the difference was negligible. Granted, a staff would be a big handy stick to beat people with, but this was so light that it wasn’t really an option. Better then to create a wand, or several wands...


“Nothus, do you have a focus of your own?” I asked, as I considered the dimensions of the femur.


She shook her head, “No, never bothered, and it’s not like I’ve got a big circle of people to help me enchant it anyway.”


“Well there’s probably enough material here for three, maybe four, wands.”


“Might as well I suppose, do you have plans for the rest of it?”


“After we make the first two?” I asked, “Yeah, I want to see how effective a set of symbols I could make.”


She frowned in thought, “Bone *is* one of the materials that can lend more power to the divination.”


“Yeah, and this isn’t just any normal bone either.”


“Well, why don’t you check?” she asked.


“Hmm, that’s a good I idea...” I said, as I fished around in my pouch.


I spoke the incantation, and drew out those symbols that most presented themselves.


---


ᚶᚷ


---


“Well that’s pretty definitive.”


“Strengthen Known,” she read aloud, “That does sound definitive.”


“I guess I know what I’m doing with my evening.”


“Is *that* all?” she teased, and I looked up from the symbols to see that she had an amused light in her eyes.


“I think you already know the answer to that,” I said wryly.


She smiled, “It’s good,” she said, “There was a while there where you always felt a little bit... well, I guess you don’t need me to tell you how you felt. It’s just good that you’re feeling happier now.”


“I suppose it makes me nicer to be around.”


“It does,” she agreed, and then she paused, “...you’re thinking about Andrew.”


“I thought you didn’t read minds,” I noted.


“I don’t,” she replied, “But I know how you feel when you think about him.”


“Caught me,” I admitted.


“You still find it odd that I consider him a friend as well, don’t you.”


“Yeah, I know he’s not a monster, but he is an asshole, and I can’t say I’m that fond of him.”


“Trust me, I know,” she smiled, “And you’re right, he’s not a monster. He has his own troubles, and he is often too willing to take those troubles out on others, but he’s still a good person.”


“Even if he is an asshole.”


She gave me a knowing look, “I’m fairly certain-”


“Alright, alright,” I said, raising my hands in defeat, “I get it, I’m not exactly a paragon of virtue either.”


She shrugged, “Even so, you both treat me with a decency that most elves seem to lack. Though I have no illusions about just why Andrew is so kind to me.”


I raised my eyebrows, “Oh?”


*Now that’s more like what I’d expect out of Andrew.*


“It’s an honest feeling at least.”


“And do you...?”


“Reciprocate his feelings?” she asked, “And how would that make you feel if I did?” she smiled.


“I wouldn’t like it,” I said flatly, “But, I’d deal with it.”


“You don’t want Andrew to be happy?” she asked.


“When you say it like that it almost makes me sound petty.”


“You, petty? *No*, that’s not possible.”

---


It took only a couple of minutes to Reshape the femur into a pair of wands, and I tossed the rest, essentially a bone ingot, into one of my pouches for later. The ingot was just barely large enough that if I was careful I might actually be able to make a third wand in addition to the symbols, and that presented certain opportunities. Rather than decide between an embedded manastone or bloodstone, I could simply have one of each. Of course, if I did embed a bloodstone in one of the wands, I would need to make two, which meant hunting down and sacrificing two stags.


Of course, I could simply purchase usable animals, both for the creation and the charging of the bloodstone, but I did not like that idea.


For the creation at least the chance of discovery was minor. I’d be purchasing one relatively small animal, probably a goat rather than a stag, and I’d probably be able to chop it up and add it to my food stores once the ritual was done. But there was still a chance, there would be one or two people in the world that knew *something,* and while chances were small, the risk was enormous. Simpler then to spend a couple of days traipsing about the forest north of the city. Catch the stag, sacrifice the stag, and then destroy the ritual site and leave the body for the ghouls.


For the charging of the stone... It had to be soul, there was just no other option. Yes, an ox was a theoretical three hundred mana, but if I was only going to get two percent of that it just wasn’t a realistic solution. I’d need fifty oxen just for the spellstone to dispel the enchantment, and another fifteen or twenty if I decided to create a spellstone to cast my modified version of Rend Soul. It wasn’t enough to be present for the creature’s death, to hide on the rooftop of a slaughterhouse or abattoir, and cast the spell with a whispered word or a few gestures. I’d need to do the killing myself, and the ritual would take a couple of minutes *at least* for each animal. And then what the hell would I do with the bodies? Yeah, they’d still be edible, but food preservation was not a well understood art on Elardia, and I’d have forty *tons* of ox to offload. I could sell it, but then there’d be some pretty significant questions asked. Some odd creepy Mage comes in, buys fifty or seventy oxen, and then shows up a few days later with forty tons of ox meat he’s trying to flog? Even if I didn’t sell it back, and dealt with it some other way, I was going to have a hard time disposing of so many bodies, and there’d still be the question of the initial purchase.


*Followed immediately by “what the hell did he do with it all?”*


I could try to buy a slaughterhouse, pass it off as me looking for business interests in the city, but then I’ve got an evil lair. Oh, and it would be a slaughter house that operates without any employees, since I wouldn’t be able to let anyone inside to see how I was killing the animals.


It was a workable problem, and I knew that I’d be able to solve it given time, but it just wasn’t worth it. Filling the stone with soul would be trivial once I had it in hand, and that course of action carried no additional risk. Yes I’d lose a year, but only one year. I was comparing the certain loss of one year, to the possible loss of an infinite number of years. Even if the risk of discovery was infinitely small, it carried and infinitely large penalty.


*And it’s not an infinitely small chance either, I’ve probably still got some of Diova’s cronies following me around and prying into my business. They’d probably have someone take a peek inside if I went with the slaughterhouse solution, especially since they know I was in the tower.*


What I needed was an escape plan. If things really did go tits up, and were absolutely unrecoverable, I needed a way out. I didn’t want to leave Victorina’s club and the friends I’d made there, but if things were bad enough that I was considering my escape route then I’d probably already be in that boat.


*Time then to bite the bullet, and try one of those planeshift spells.*


---


Despite my initial giddiness at finding the spells, I’d been hesitant to cast them. My greatest fear had been that I might not be able to make it back, or that the world I landed in would lack magic, but if I’d been thinking rationally I’d have known that it was safe. Probably. Whoever had wrote the book had made it back after all, and not just from one alternate world, but three.


I made my way out of the city only a little after I finished my little get together with Nothus, and found a place just a little north of the city on a lightly sloping hill. From here I could see the city proper, the two lobed design of the magical and non-magical portions reminding me of a cell undergoing mitosis, along with the large lake that was just south of the city. With the hawk vision amulet active I could even see the Patrician guildhall on the far end of the lake.


From here I’d be able to see any differences between the two worlds immediately, and unless things were too different I’d be far enough from the city not to be noticed.


“Something something, one big step for me, a giant leap or whatever,” I muttered, as I flipped through my phone to find the ritual. It wasn’t a simple matter, stepping across into another dimension, and it wasn’t quick. Teleport’s casting time could be cut down to less than a second if you weren’t going far and put in a little extra energy, that was not the case with Plane Shift. It took me over an hour to finish the casting.


---


The first thing I saw when I blinked into existence on the other side, was the trees.


Lots of trees.


The world I’d selected had been Elardia Primal Alpha, and now I knew why it was referred to as ‘Primal’. Nimre, the city, was gone, and in it’s place was a fucking lot of trees. Rather than stand on the southern edge of the forest, it appeared as if I was deep within. Even with the hawk vision amulet, I couldn’t make out the lake that had lain on the far side of the city, the trees were just too thick.


I turned around slowly, finding yet more of the same thick forests all around, and not much of interest.


For all intents and purposes I was standing on an entirely different *planet*, but I really just felt underwhelmed.


I opened up Excel on my phone, and made some notes as I made made my way back down the slope to where Nimre would be back on Elardia Primary.


I did not find any signs of civilization as I walked through the ‘city’, and not only was there absolutely no construction, I couldn’t see anything to indicate that there had *ever* been anything built on this site. As far as I could tell Elardia Primal Alpha was basically Elardia Primary, minus intelligent life.


Of course, it was also possible that there were elves to be found elsewhere on the continent, or on other continents, but I didn’t really have the means to travel far. Yes, I could teleport, but I’d be doing that without any active beacons so my range would be limited to a couple of kilometres.


I stopped my little walk once I’d reached the shore of the lake, and was not surprised to find thick forest in place of the guildhall that had previously occupied the shore.


*Or is it a bank if it’s a lake? Bank, shore, maybe edge? Whatever. Time for the moment of truth, am I actually going to be able to get home?*


The ‘moment’ lasted over an hour as I ran through the ritual again, but eventually I got through it, and had my answer.


---


*Yes I can, apparently.*


There was the League of Patricians’ guildhall on the far bank, shore, or edge, and upon turning around I was greeted with the sight of the city’s imposing marble walls.


I glanced down at my watch, and it reported that it was 5:34 on November 9th. The time at least was correct, the date however was not. It was close, but we weren’t quite that far into autumn, and it felt more like October at the moment.


No, November 9th was not an accurate record of the current local date, instead it told me how long I’d been on Elardia. January 1st had been that first day I’d woken up after my crash, and the first day I’d met Sila and Harp. With the watch reporting November 9th that made this day three hundred and thirteen, which meant that I’d been at the University for a little over a hundred days.


*Damn, a hundred days? It’s felt a lot longer than that.*


I decided against trying another of the spells, it was getting late, and I’d need another two hours just for the trip there and back. If those other two worlds were anything like the first then I’d be dropping into untamed wilderness, and I didn’t really want a wolf sneaking up on me while I was distracted with the ritual.


I’d wait until tomorrow to check out the other two worlds, and I’d also take the opportunity to try to find a stag. Tracking down fifty wild oxen or a hundred wild deer probably wouldn’t be practical, but at least this way I’d have a way to create it at least without risking discovery.

----

I stepped out of the ensuite, my hair still damp from the bath, to find Halea already nestled in among the folds of silk that covered my bed.

“Mmm, Quinn,” Halea smouldered, “Feel like trying something new?”


“Oh, trying to broaden my horizons?” I asked, as I shrugged out of the bathrobe, and slipped in next to her.


“Something like that,” she said, as she rolled over to plant an elbow on my chest, “Do you know what this is?” she asked, holding up a thumb sized crystal that seemed to be lit from within by a soft pink light.


The crystal reminded me of those that we’d recovered during our ill fated trip to the mine. The ones we’d turned into manastones, and if not for the fact that this one was tinged pink I would have assumed that it was just another manastone. Though this one was strung from a fine gold chain.


“Looks like a pink manastone,” I stated obviously, as I reached up to run a hand through her hair.


“More or less,” she said, biting her lower lip, “This one is special though.”


“How special?” I asked through narrowed eyes.


“Well, it’s recharged in a very interesting way,” she purred, as she slipped her other hand under the covers and along my belly.


“Really?” I asked, suddenly quite interested, but probably not in the way Halea had intended, “Is it also capable of storing more mana than a normal manastone?”


*If this is the Halea version of a bloodstone then maybe... And I’m pretty sure I’d enjoy the process of getting it charged up.*


“Not really,” she admitted, “It’s more of a curiosity than anything else. It probably would have been more practical to turn this crystal into a normal stone, but this is much more *fun*.”


“Damn,” I sighed.


*Looks like I’ve got to go with the bloodstone.*


She must have noticed something, either in my expression or in the lack of *response* to her touch, because she narrowed her eyes, “You have something planned? And you need a lot of mana for this plan?”


“Yeah, and probably all in one shot, which means a damn big manastone of some sort. I might be able to settle for a couple smaller stones, but they’d still need to be able to store a hell of a lot of mana.”


“Mmm, there aren't many substitutes for size,” she smirked, “Size and structure, that’s what matters when it comes to manastones. Gemstones have fantastic structure, but are often quite small. Or you go for something with worse structure, but greater size, like this,” she said, dangling the pink manastone in front of my eyes, “The crystals we recovered aren't worth anything to a jeweler, and their structure is pretty mediocre, but they make up for it in size.”


“What gemstones are usually considered the best?” I asked.


She rolled her eyes, obviously she thought that my priorities were out of order, “Diamonds usually, something about their pure crystal structure, Neferoy could probably tell you more about though. But why don’t we set that aside fo-”


“Diamonds,” I breathed, eyes growing wide.


“For fext’s sake Quinn,” Halea hissed incredulously.


“Diamonds Halea, Diamonds! A diamond is just a crystal of pure carbon, which *means...*”


I turned away from Halea’s admittedly beautiful face to look at one of my armchairs, over which I’d draped my belt of extradimensional pouches. Extradimensional pouches which held an ingot made of pure carbon nanotubes, that was larger even than two of my fists set together.


*Even if it was just a hunk of the same low grade crystal Halea’s little toy is made of... It’s got to be a couple of orders of magnitude larger. And it’s* ***not*** *just a hunk of low grade crystal, it might as well be solid diamond. Hell, it might even be better.*


“Quinn,” Halea sighed, “If there’s something else you’d rather be- Oh!” she yelped, as I rolled the two of us over, leaving myself on top, “*Now* what’s got you all worked up?” she said in an exasperated tone, “Not that I’m complaining.”


“I’ll tell you after,” I said grinning widely, “But I think we’re going to have some work to do.”


---
